editorialDecl.p: EEBO-TCP is a partnership between the Universities of Michigan and Oxford and the publisher ProQuest to create accurately transcribed and encoded texts based on the image sets published by ProQuest via their Early English Books Online (EEBO) database (http://eebo.chadwyck.com). The general aim of EEBO-TCP is to encode one copy (usually the first edition) of every monographic English-language title published between 1473 and 1700 available in EEBO.

EEBO-TCP aimed to produce large quantities of textual data within the usual project restraints of time and funding, and therefore chose to create diplomatic transcriptions (as opposed to critical editions) with light-touch, mainly structural encoding based on the Text Encoding Initiative (http://www.tei-c.org).

The EEBO-TCP project was divided into two phases. The 25,368 texts created during Phase 1 of the project (2000-2009), initially available only to institutions that contributed to their creation, were released into the public domain on 1 January 2015. The approximately 40,000 texts produced during Phase 2 (2009- ), of which 34,963 had been released as of 2020, originally similarly restricted, were similarly freed from all restrictions on 1 August 2020. As of that date anyone is free to take and use these texts for any purpose (modify them, annotate them, distribute them, etc.). But we do respectfully request that due credit and attribution be given to their original source.
Users should be aware of the process of creating the TCP texts, and therefore of any assumptions that can be made about the data.

Text selection was based on the New Cambridge Bibliography of English Literature (NCBEL). If an author (or for an anonymous work, the title) appears in NCBEL, then their works are eligible for inclusion. Selection was intended to range over a wide variety of subject areas, to reflect the true nature of the print record of the period. In general, first editions of a works in English were prioritized, although there are a number of works in other languages, notably Latin and Welsh, included and sometimes a second or later edition of a work was chosen if there was a compelling reason to do so.

Image sets were sent to external keying companies for transcription and basic encoding. Quality assurance was then carried out by editorial teams in Oxford and Michigan. 5% (or 5 pages, whichever is the greater) of each text was proofread for accuracy and those which did not meet QA standards were returned to the keyers to be redone. After proofreading, the encoding was enhanced and/or corrected and characters marked as illegible were corrected where possible up to a limit of 100 instances per text. Any remaining illegibles were encoded as <gap>s. Understanding these processes should make clear that, while the overall quality of TCP data is very good, some errors will remain and some readable characters will be marked as illegible. Users should bear in mind that in all likelihood such instances will never have been looked at by a TCP editor.
The texts were encoded and linked to page images in accordance with level 4 of the TEI in Libraries guidelines.

Copies of the texts have been issued variously as SGML (TCP schema; ASCII text with mnemonic sdata character entities); displayable XML (TCP schema; characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or text strings within braces); or lossless XML (TEI P5, characters represented either as UTF-8 Unicode or TEI g elements).
Keying and markup guidelines are available at the Text Creation Partnership web site.

div.p: THE Fa ••• ous Citizen, OR, THE Melancholy Viſioner. A COMEDY. As it was Acted at the DUKE'S THEATRE.
LONDON, Printed for Thomas Maddocks, at the upper end of Ship Yard▪ without Temple Bar, 1685.

lg.l: HOW cruelly do Poets rack their Brains!
For ſmall Applauſe, and little or no gains;
Courting your ſick and ſqueamiſh Appetite,
Still with freſh pleaſure, and a new delight.
They ſtrive to pleaſe you, with no little pain,
And try to humor you in every ſtrain,
From the high Rant, of Thundring, Rhiming Verſe,
To mimic Baudy Droll, and humble Farce.
Lovers from every place, of every Age,
Their Tragic Muſe have brought upon the Stage,
Whilſt Comic Satyr ſtrove to repreſent
All ſorts of Fools, to give you all content.
Poets have robb'd the Earth, Heav'n, Air and Seas
Of Objects, trying every way to pleaſe,
With Songs, with Dances, and with painted Scenes,
With Drums, with Trumpets, and with fine Machines,
They've ſhewn you Angels, Spirits, Devils too,
Hoping to find ſome way to pleaſure you
With ſomething that was very rare or new:
All this for you have drudging Poets done,
Loſing the dear-bought Fame they once had won.
You come not now ſharp ſet, pleas'd with each bit
Of Tragic Sence, and ſeaſon'd Comic Wit;
But now you come with Stomachs, as if full,
Taſt nothing, but cry out, the Poets dull.
Not much unlike to an ill-natur'd Gueſt,
Who having fill'd his Belly, blames the Feaſt.
When you'll ſcarce come to'a noted Poets Treat,
Or when you do, will hardly like the Meat,
Our Poets fears, cloy'd with ſuch various Feaſts,
He ſhan't find any thing to pleaſe our Gueſts:
That nothing with pall'd Appetites will down,
Unleſs he brings ſome Fruit you have not known.
Poets have been ſo laviſh and ſo kind,
New Characters are very hard to find,
And all the Fools, Court, City, Country yield,
Already have been muſter'd in this Field:
But he at laſt did on ſome Mad-Men light,
With whom he'll entertain you here to Night;
Hoping that his Fanatic Melancollicks
Will make you laugh, at their unuſual Frolicks:
What e're the Title in the Bill may ſay,
He thinks 'twill prove no Melanchollick Play.
SEE Gentlemen, I now am Sober grown,
And all Fanatic Turbulence diſown:
I who did Rail, and roar againſt the Times,
And ſtill was rakeing in the Kingdoms Crimes,
Who meddled with all matters, and made known
All Faults, but never told, nor ſaw my own,
In ſilence now, Crimes, Follies, Madneſs too,
Can ſee, and laugh, and ſnear like ſome of you.
Bethlem's a Bleſſed Hoſpital, and fit
T'effect the Cure of each crack'd Brain and Wit,
And may deſerve a Song, as well I tro,
As th' Monument, or Weather-cock of Bow:
Thither let all Fanatics of this Age,
Who trouble both the Church, the State and Stage
Be ſent; ſpare dyet, whipping, letting Bloud
Is far more proper, and may do more good
T' all who run mad in Coffe-houſe and Ale-houſe,
Than either Newgate, Pillory or Gallows.
Send thither every Lay and Frantick Widgeon,
Who coble, botch, patch, and tranſlate Religion;
Who leave their Awles, their Needles, Hammers, Shears,
To meddle with, and prate of State Affairs:
Who cry down Vice, yet love a private Whore,
Theſe, and alas! to name, too many more,
Want Doctor Quibus Pill of Hellebore.
You Critticks too, who damn our Poets ſo,
Pray do not think that you ſhall Scot-Free go;
For all you half-brain'd Wits, who never fail,
Againſt both Poets, and their Plays to rail,
Who ſtill find fault, tho oft told of it here,
Like our mad Ariſtotle and Scalliger,
In Bethlem 'mong the reſt ought to appear.
I'll ſay no more, leſt I ſhould tedious grow,
But only make one Prayer e're I go.
With this New Play, may you all pleaſed be
May we all live in peace, and all agree,
And may all Turbulents find Cure like Me.

div.head: Dramatis Perſonae.

list.label: Timothy Turbulent, One that hates all ſorts of Government and Governours, and is always railing againſt the Times, Guardian to his Neece Mrs. Well-bred.
Furniſh, Nephew to Mr. Turbulent, a ſwaggering, debauched Perſon, who has nothing, lives by his Wits, yet furniſhes others with Money and Goods.
Hangby, A Creature of Furniſh's, and a Cheat.
Grin Sneak, A great Projector, and a Fop.
Fiincal Cringe, A Balderdaſh Poet, and an Apiſh Citizen, makes love to Mrs. Wellbred.
Rabſheka Sly, A Creature, of Mr. Turbulent's, and one of his private Cabal, a private Sinner, and Railer againſt the Times.
Abednego Suck-Thumb, Another Creature of Turbulent's.
Mr. Fairlove, A Gentleman of Senſe and Underſtanding, in love with Mrs. Lucy.
Friendly, Of his acquaintance, averſe to Marriage.
Dr. Quibus, A French Doctor, that gives Phyſick to Turbulent.
Pollux, Turbulents Man.

list.head: WOMEN.
list.label: Mrs. Turbulent. —
Lady Medler, A very buſie, Match making Lady, a pretender to get Pattents for Sneak.
Lucia Well-bred, Neece to Mr. Turbulent, in Love with Fairlove.
Priſcilla, Turbulent's Daughter, A Quaker, yet deſirous to be thought Learned.
Mrs. Sly, Wife to Rabſheka.

div.p: Mad-Men and Women, Conſtables, Drawers, Fidlers.—

div.head: SCENE. I.
MOORFIELDS.
ACT I.
div.stage: Enter Pollux alone, telling ſome Braſs Farthings ont of one hand into the other.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: ONE, Two, Three, Four, Five, Six, Seven, Eight, with theſe Eight Farthings muſt I purchaſe Six ſeveral ſorts of Commodities: Very good—what a pretty Office I have? 'tis the chief of my work to trot about theſe Errands all day long, for a covetous, ſtingy, griping old Devil my Maſter, who feeds me with Leek Porredg and Cow-Heels, whilſt he fills his own Guts with cramb'd Chickens, Turky-Eggs, and white Broaths, till he lays it up again— Odsnigs I have loſt one of my Braſs Guinies —

div.stage: kneels as to look his farthing.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why how now Pol? what art thou poaking for i'the dirt?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O Mr. Fair-love, I am undone, I have loſt the Eighth Part of my Purchaſe-Money, I was going to lay out for my Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come give it o're, here, I'll make it up for thee, what haſt loſt?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, not much, but a Farthing: it is but eating our Cowheel without Muſtard to day.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Here Pol— here's a Shilling for thee.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Thank you Sir, if I could but loſe money thus every day, and gain by the loſs, I ſhould grow rich, like thoſe who loſe a Hundred Pound by a Fire, procure a charitable Brief, with one more, and get Six Hundred Pounds by it.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Well Pol, I ſee you know the World, but prethe let Mrs. Lucy know that I am in this Walk, and would willingly kiſs her hand; you know Pollux I dare not be ſeen in Mr. Turbulent's Houſe, and Mrs. Lucy has deſired me to forbear coming thither her ſelf.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I know it Sir, very well: I ſhall give her notice of your being here inſtantly; but ſhe is ſo buſy, I believe ſhe cannot ſteal forth at this time.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why Pol? what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O Sir, My Maſter has taken Phyſick to day— a kind of grumbling came over his Maw, which I doubt was a Surfeit got by eating of Raſhers of Bacon and poatch'd Eggs th'other day, with his Nephew Furniſh: but Doctor Quibus, the gibberiſh— ſputtering French Doctor, tells him it is Melancholy, and that he muſt purge it away.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And what is all this to Mrs. Lucy? Methinks now he is ty'd to his Cloſe-ſtool, ſhe may the better leave the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I tell yon Sir, the whole Family is employed, and all too little, to wait on him: He is turbulent to purpoſe, for a little yellowiſh Powder the Doctor gave him, which he called Enemetic, has ſo claw'd him off, that there is the Devil and all to do with him. I ſhall be Hang'd for ſtaying.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But however, I don't ſee, but that Mrs. Lucy may get forth for all this.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Nay, You won't hear me, my Miſtreſs holds his head whilſt he diſcharges; my young Miſtreſs Priſcilla holds the Baſon to catch the Stream forſooth, and your fair Miſtreſs Lucy warms the Napkins to rub the Sweat off from his Countenance.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: A good employment— Well Pol, however do you but whiſper her that I am here, and leave the reſt to her tender diſcretion.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Sir, your Servant— I will not fail to tread on her Toe, and lay my Lips to her Ear immediately.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Frank Fairelove— What the Devil do you do here? Is it to ſnuff the Air of Bun-fields? or have you a City Intrigue, to meet ſome Shop-keepers Wife?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I may as well ask you, what you do here? you belong to the other end of the Town as well as I.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why, it lay in my way, and I was paſſing the Fields, as a man does a Ford in a River, as ſuddenly as I can, I long to be out of them, they ſtink of City-Dog-houſe. But you I ſee are taking your ſerious turns here, as if it were for Recreation or Meditation, or that you took more delight in Moor-Fields than in the Trainſwept Malt, or glorious Hide-Park.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why, Will. Friendly, do you ſpeak againſt a place that you know not? you are much miſtaken in ſuppoſing here is no Recreation.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Yes, here are Recreations indeed, to ſee the wenches dry their Cloaths, and the Boys play at Graſs-Cat, the Archers in Finsbury to ſhoot at Rovers, and Nine-pin-Alleys, and Bawdyhouſes in every Quarter; what other Recreations canſt find?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p:
Yes, all the Varieties thou canſt imagine. Oh the ſeveral ſorts of People that walk in theſe Fields, the Saint, the Sot, the
Cheat, • he Cully, the Grave, the Frollick, the Wiſe, the Fool, 〈◊〉 Melancholy, the Religious, the Fanatic, the Uſurers, the Philoſophers, the Alchymiſts, the Quacks, the Shop-keeper, from the Mercer to the Cobler, and Stocking-mender, with all their Wives, Daughters, Neeces and Maidens.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Fairly reckoned, you forgot the Mad-men too, in Bethlem, they make part of the Rarities. But methinks St. James's Park, and the fair Bevie, that is there to be ſeen every Night, ſhould have more attraction. The bright, fair, buckſom, witty, fine, willing and airy Girles at that end of the Town, ſhould give more delight than green Aprons, and Grogaram Gowns or Petticoats that ſtink of Soap and Tallow, or the Cypreſs Cheſts and Lavender.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Every man as he likes. I know your aim is at ſome fine, witty, frollic, buckſom Miſs, which ſome unmannerly Puppies call Wenches, and others moſt abominably aſperſe by the term of Whore. Why Faith Will this place is not without thoſe Creatures, and plenty of them too, of all ſorts and ſizes, though perhaps not ſo well prinkum prankum'd, or ſo modiſhly rigg'd: Theſe are a ſort of demure Whores, with little Rings upon their Foreheads, a ſtrait Hood, and a narrow diminitive Colverteen Pinner, that makes them look ſo Saint-like, that you would ſwear 'em the Daughters of innocence it ſelf.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is ſomething to the purpoſe, I like the place the better for that; but prethe be plain with thy Friend, and do not conceal thy Intrigue: who is it you are in queſt of, that has ſo ſtrong a Cart-Rope, as to draw thee from all the fine things in the Mall, to theſe ſtinking Tents of Bottle Ale and ruſty Bacon? ſure 'tmuſt be ſome rare piece: Or art thou cloy'd with Partridge and Pheaſant, and long'ſt after Hung-Beef, muſty Swines-fleſh, or Raſhers on the dirty Coales?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You are ſtill beſides the Mark Will. 'tis no ordinary Game that I hunt in theſe Fields.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why ſo ſly Frank? I never had a Miſs or Intrigue yet, but I diſcovered it to thee; this is unkindly, the very Air of this place ſpoils your good nature.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I will tell you then, I am damnably, deſperately, deeply in Love, and ſo have bin ſeveral Moneths too, and with an honeſt, witty, beautiful, well-bred, diſcreet, young Lady, and one that has Money boy to boot.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: To have bin in Love for ſeveral Moneths, is no ſuch ſtrange thing, with a witty, beautiful, well-bred, diſcreet, young Lady; but if ſhe be honeſt, and you cannot hope to make her otherways, what do you do with her?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I ſee you follow your old Game Will— But I aſſure thee, mine is an honourable and lawful, and meer Matrimonial Deſign.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p:
Heavens forbid— Matrimonial Love ſay you? thou
art not ſo intoxicated yet? what Marry, when all the Wo …
…
ſake their Wives, and fall to keeping? when 'tis grown as much out of Faſhion as Trunk Breeches; thou haſt convers'd fairly with Moor-Fields.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Away, away, let's have no tilting againſt Marriage, the Theam is grown thred-bare, there is ſcarce a Comedy without it, the Poets and the Stage have laught at it ſo long, that they begin to be laught at themſelves for it. I tell thee Will. Friendly, mine is a fair, honeſt, downright, Matrimonial-Love, with a very honeſt fair, young, witty Gentlewoman, and now, in truth, you have my whole Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If it be ſo, I think thou art turned an honeſt, down-right, plain-dealing Sot. Doſt not thou know that there is not a more unbecoming thing in Nature, than to ſee a Gentleman handing and waiting on his Wife.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that, I have therefore withdrawn my ſelf to this end of the Town, even to Moor-Fields, where 'tis no ſhame to do ſo; Men and their Wives ordinarily walk here together very lovingly.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Ay, Citizens and Shop-keepers, who are wedded to their old Faſhions.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I believe it will grow in Faſhion again, at the other end of the Town ſhortly: Miſſes are ſo very chargeable, humorſome, proud, impertinent and tyrannical, that no Wife in the World can be more. But I am reſolv'd, and am not now to be ſhaken, therefore forbear.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But may not I ſee this fine, powerful Charm of yours?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes, you may in time, I am not ſhy, and I think need not be jealous of thee; for thou canſt love nothing that's honeſt.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: That's becauſe I could never meet with that Chimoera, but you it ſeems, have found this rare Jewel.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Did you know her you would ſay ſo in Earneſt, ſhe is a Jewel out ſhewn in the Dark, which makes her Carbuncle-like, to ſhine the brighter.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: If it ben't i'the dark, 'tis ſuch a hole, I ſhould ne'r have fought for a Jewel in.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: That's nothing to the Family ſhe lives in, and to the People ſhe is forc'd to converſe with.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Well, who is ſhe? her Name, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why I'll tell thee, her name is Lucia, Well-bred, a Gentlemans Daughter, who dying, left her under the Guardianſhip of one Mr. Timothy Turbulent, whoſe Wife was Siſter to her Father. Now he, with his hypocritical Sanctity, got ſo far into the Eſteem of his Brother-in-Law, that he left his Daughter to his Care, with full power to ſee her beſtowed in Marriage, but her Portion he committed to the ſafe keeping of the Chamber of London, which is 5000. Pounds.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: He was wiſe in that.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: This Mr. Turbulent is one that is ſtill Railing againſt the Times, the Court, the King, the Church, the Government, and almoſt every thing that ſtands in his way, loves to ſpeak Treaſon privately, and has a great delight and faculty that way.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A good Guardian.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: His Wife is one that has walk'd throw all Religions, and at laſt is come into the Society of the Sweet Singers. His Daughter is an impertinent, and unmannerly Quaker, yet pretends to Knowledge, Learning and Logick.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: 'Fore George, your Jewel's well ſet.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Beſides, The Gang that follows this Mr. Turbulent, and viſits his Houſe, of Anabaptiſts, Vitioneers, Quakers, Hypocrites, Cheats and Fools of all ſorts; which are the only People, my Miſtreſs is ſuffered to converſe with.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: But in what Predicament ſtard you with your Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: The buſineſs of Wooing is paſt, we are come to a Concluſion; but Mr. Turbulent knowing me to be one of the un-ſanctifiedend of the Town (as he calls it) has abſolutely forbid me all entrance into his Manſion, ſo that I cannot ſee Lucy, but by ſtealth.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou deſerveſt this Gentlewoman, who e'r ſhe be, for ventring into ſuch a Place and People for her ſake— 'Tis far beyond the Voyage of Orpheus for Euridice, or of Jaſon for the Golden Fleece, the Furies and the Dragons and wild Bulls, were not ſo dangerous as theſe ſort of People thou haſt named.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You may ſee by this the power of Love, that I can walk with pleaſure under theſe Trees, the contemplation of Pay-day Melancholy.

div.stage: Enter Cringe ſinging, dreſt moſt exactly with Ribbons and —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Fa la fal fal la la fa la fa—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Whom have we here? a kind of a Morrice-dancer by his trip and trim.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: O Sir, 'tis my Rival, one that Mr. Turbulent deſigns for Lucies Husband, he is a Mercer of Lombard-Street, his name is Finical Cringe.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Fa la la fal la la—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A pretty ſpruce airy What d'ye lack Sir.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes, he learns to ſing, dance, fence and to play of the Violin, ſcorns to be like the Citizens, but ſcurvily imitates the Courtiers. Nay he is a pretender to Poetry, makes Sonnets and Acroſticks on his Miſtreſs Name. He goes duly to Pinners Hall with Mr. Turbulent, where he writes the Sermons, and when he comes home, privately reads Plays and Romances. To this Ape has Mr. Turbulent promiſed Mrs. Lucy, for which he is to have 500 l. of her Portion for his Daughter Priſcilla.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Why doſt not beat him, but ſuffer him to court thy Mrs.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p:
What, beat an Aſs— there is no danger of 〈…〉
Lucies only diverſion, and ſerves to make her ſport as much as • Monkie. Oh he ſees us—

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Mr Fairelove, honoured Mr. Fairelove, I kiſs your hand, humbly kiſs your hand heh—heh—

lg.l: This is your friend heh!
I humbly kiſs yours heh—

div.stage: ſalutes them with many fine Bows and Cringes.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Your ſervant Sir, whither are you going Mr. Cringe? what to ſee Mrs. Lucy I warrant.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I am going to make her my daily Viſit heh, and to illuminate my ſelf by her luſtre heh —

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You are a happy man Mr. Cringe— you are going to offer ſome Copy of Verſes now to her fair hands—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Who I? fa la fa la la— I can a little at Poetry— but you have ſo many better Poets at your end of the Town heh, heh, that you diſlike us City Wits, heh—

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: Pox on him for a Baboon, what do you diſcourſe with him ſo long for?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee be quiet, he will ſhew his Verſes now, either ſtolen out of ſome Play-Book, or of his own making.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What does the Coxcomb heh ſo at us?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Oh! 'tis his word of Expectation, the Fop thinks it a grace, and has us'd himſelf ſo long to't, he cannot ſpeak ten words without it, and it makes up a great part of his Oratory— ſee he's a pulling out his Papers,

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: This is Moor-fields—

div.stage: Cringe reads to himſelf and ſmiles.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come, come Mr. Cringe, let us ſee your Raptures, you are reading there— my Friend here is a very good Judg of Verſes.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: 'Tis a pretty Conceit heh, a very pretty conceit heh —

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come what is't, let's ſee it.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why 'tis a Copy of Verſes of a Pin that fell from Mrs. Lucies Sleeve, and I put it upon mine heh— carried it home heh, and this Morning I made theſe Verſes heh, which I am going to preſent her, with her Pin again heh; is it not a pretty Conceit heh?—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Yes, and ſhews much Wit, the Great Virgil did not diſdain to write on a Gnat, and a Fly, and a Flea; yea a Louſe, has been the Theam of the Witty Poets, among which we will place your Piu.

sp.speaker: Cring.
sp.p: The Conceit is new I aſſure you, heh — here Mr. Fairelove, you ſhall read 'em — heh!

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: No, by no means, you will grace 'em beſt your ſelf — your Poets always love to read their own Verſes, they know where to give the Emphaſis, and how to accent them, with the true riſe and fall of the Voice —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Well then —
Upon a Pin dropt from Mrs. Lucies fair Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Had it not been better— upon fair Mrs. Lucies Sleeve.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, that is not ſo new— Mark the Conceit heh.
Reads—

l.hi: Return ſweet Pin, unto my ſowr ſweet foe,
Tell how her ſecret Charms do play their part,

lg.l: How like the dart of Cupid, thou doſt ſhow,

l.hi: Which from her eyes, ſhot through my loving heart.
A wondrous thing! thy touch was harmleſs to me,
And where thou touch'd me not, thou didſt undo me.

sp.p: How do you like it heh?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Excellent.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Reads—

l.hi: Yet tell, dear Pin, that thy Enchanted Touch
Did ſweeten ſo the Sleeve, where it was caſt,
That there was nothing grieved me ſo much,
As the remembrance of my Freedom paſt,
For who may be her Captive, and be free,
A Gally Slave, lives happier than he.

sp.p: what ſay you hey—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Very good—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Reads—

l.hi: So be thou gone, and yet go not I pray,
Go not, ſweet Pin, O go not back at all,
But prick my heart ſo hard, that Night and Day,
In Death and Liſe, it be her Beauties Thrall;
And yet, even go, for Duty ſo commands,
Go gentle Pin again, to her fair hands.

sp.p: Mark that heh, and then I preſent the Pin heh, a merry Conceit, heh, a Morning Meditation, heh— fal la la la fal fa lay— but your friend does not tell me how he likes it heh.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Very ſcurvily heh— why this Fool is madder than any in Bedlam—prethe let me kick him going—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: By no means— did you make theſe Verſes Mr. Cringe?

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Yes Sir—and off hand, this Morning, I did not ſtudy much for 'em.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I dare ſwear he did not.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But I doubt you ſtole 'em Mr. Cringe, for I remember I ſaw the very ſame Verſes, with little alteration on a Scarf, Printed among Collection of rare Poems.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Aſide— Who'd think he ſhould have ſeen that Book— I thought it had been out of Print, I do but as the greateſt Wits do, ſteal one from another, but I had as good have made 'em, for it loſt as much Labour and Oyl, as the Poets ſay, to turn a Scarf into a Pin heh—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I am ſure you have turn'd your ſelf into a Wood-Cock— Here's a Moorfield Poet and City Wit, with all my heart— ' •• id Fairlove, art bewitch'd, to hold any longer converſe with this Fool, and finical 〈◊〉 Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p:
Mr. Fairlove, your Servant, heh. I ſee your friend is …
pory and huffy heh— your ſervant, your ſervant, fa la la fa la la—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Why are you ſo angry Will— would you have converſe with none but Philoſophers— or would you have the man have more Wit than God has given him?

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: No, Natural folly does not offend me, a Jack Adams, a Clown, a Jobbernole; but theſe fools, that take pains, and are induſtrious, and laborious to ſhew their follies, ever make me angry, I can't laugh at 'em.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But I can— prethee let's withdraw— I ſee more Company, that will be worſe offenſive to me, for I hate Knaves, and there are a couple of ſufficient ones.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Prethe, who are they?—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come this way, I'll tell thee—

That is one Furniſh, a Siſters Son of Mr. Turbulent, a very Cheat, has nothing, yet furniſhes all the needy Lords of the Town with money, keeps his Coach, his Houſe well furniſh'd, ſpends high, keeps his Whores, his Footmen, French-Man, &c. and all by his Wits.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: I like ſuch a man very well, Knaves are no offence to me, they are very neceſſary Common Wealth-men, and are as good as a Cat in a Houſe, to pray upon the Vermin Fools. Would there were more of them; but who's there—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis one Hangby, a creature of his, and a Conſpirator in his Cheats— they come this way, let's ſheere off into the next Walk.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: A Pox of ill luck, my Uncle Turbulent has taken Phyſick to day, and I cannot have the opportunity of getting him forth. I can do no good with him, whilſt the old Hag my Aunt is with him. Nothing will open his heart, but good Sack and Sugar, or ſweet Metheglin, or elſe a Brace of Steaming Capons, with all the accoutrements.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Nay, he is a Devil at Eating, he lays in like Wood a Kent, when he eats on Free Coſt.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: He had better eat at a ten Shilling Ordinary, every time he eats with me, I have the right way to coaks him. I know his humour Jack— But I'm at a Deviliſh Plunge for this 50 l. to ſtop the Execution that is coming out againſt my Goods; my Coach and Horſes are in jeopardy.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Is it poſſible you can want money already? it is not many days ſince I ſaw thee as rich as a Banker, and rolling in Guinies.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Faith they're all gone— flown boy— they never ſtay long with me — Doſt not ſee what ſhoales I have following me, that I am fain to forſake my Lodging, or get out on't by 5 in the morning, to avoid them, yet wonder that theſe ſums ſhould be ſo ſoon gone.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: You ſay true.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Beſides there is Sir William Needy, Mr Litttlewit, Mr. Pennyleſs, Mr. Marland, and 40 more that I have furniſhed, and muſt furniſh as faſt as I can. But Puppies—Puppies Jack begin to grow thin; if I could but meet with them as often as I could defire, I ſhould do well enough.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But well as to this 50 l. 'tis a ſmall Sum; I never knew thee ſo gravell'd before for ſuch a little Modicum—what no Truſt in the City—what! has the Lace-man ſmelt thee? never a Claret-Merchant! Will the Sadler truſt no more Sadles to furniſh the Troops going to Flanders, ne're a Draper—Where are your Setters and Ferriters for ſecurity; are there no Tradeſmen now ready to break, whoſe Credit is good enough to be bound for a 100 l. or ſo, and go ſnips. Where is your honeſt Rogue Scrivener to draw in hah?
sp.stage: Furniſh is all this while muſing.
sp.p: What man! a la mort?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: This Uncle of mine vexes me—He begins to hearken to the Old Beldame his Wife, who has loſt all her Teeth with ſcolding; and her Lips are worn ſo thin that they will not keep her Noſe and her Chin from meeting.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: I tell thee Jack I have not ſufficiently ſqueez'd this Uncle of mine—He milks hard now, and I take the more pleaſure in it. Oh! the delight I take of putting the Dice upon a wary Fop. If he be covetous let me alone to deal with him. 'Twas no leſs than 30 in the hundred advantage, with good ſecurity, that made this preciſe Aſs my Uncle part with his 500 l. for ſo much I have had, which he is never like to ſee again, and this 50 l. to Boot.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But how?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Let me alone—Go you away, preſently diſrobe your ſelf; off with your Cloaths, your Sword, Wig, and Hat—Put your ſelf nimbly into a black Sute of Grogran, below the Knees, a broad skirted Doublet, and Girdle about the middle, and a ſhort black Cloak ſquirted down before with black Taffity, a broad brim'd Hat, with a great twiſted Hatband with a Roſe at the end of it—Your Hair is ſlink enough, and of the preciſe Cut without your Perriwig: good Jack be nimble, and meet me at the Popes Head Tavern, near to my Uncles, about 3 a Clock in the Afternoon. I will prepare him for you.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I have a Broker in Long-Lane that ſoon will Attire me in any Garb. I have ſerved you I'm ſure in all Habits, from the Lord to that Clown, nay to the Skip-kennel—But what muſt I do?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Prethee be not impertinent, I think thou art grown dull. Obſerve your Cue—You are to be a Suter to my Couſin Priſcilla.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Enough—enough—I have you i' my Noddle—fear me not—Ile be with you without fail.

sp.speaker: Farn.
sp.p: And I muſt in the mean time try my skill to get my Uncle to the Tavern, now he has taken Phiſick, from that Female Devil my Aunt, whom I dread more than the ſight of a Baſilisk.
How now Mr. Sneak — Prethee wha'ts become of the Captain your great Companion, that was to go on the expedition to conquer the Iſland of Formoſa.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: He had not patience till my Lady Medler could get the Commiſſion, and ſo he is gone to ſell Ale at Wapping.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: God the better Employment by half, and more to be got by it.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: You are always an Infidel Mr. Furniſh, but I am come to ask ſeriouſly your advice, whether I ſhould accept an Employ that is now offered me, or no?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Accept? what the Devil elſe ſhould you do but accept?

Thou haſt not had ſix pence in thy Pocket this ſix Moneths to my knowledg but what I have furniſhed thee with, to go to the Coffie-Houſes to meet your damned cheating Roguiſh Projectors. If thou gets no more by pimping than thou doeſt by projecting, we ſhall ſee through this ſlender Body of thine ſhortly. But what in the Name of Wonder, is this Place or Employ that is offered you?

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: I am offered two Places to go Governour of Poetan, or Conſul of Marſielles—which ſhall I take?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Poetan, where is that?

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: It is a great Kingdom in the Weſt Indies, for which I am to raiſe 10000 l and I to go Governour.
'Tis a great way off Mr. Sneak, I ſhould rather be Conſul of Marſielles.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: I am of your mind, my Lady Medler has as good as got me the Patent—Faith Il'e ſend thee good ſtore of Muſcat.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Conſul of Marſielles, hah hah hah—a goodly Conſul— But hark you Mr. Conſul Sneak, what will then become of all your Projects if you go? will you leave all your Concerns in your Black Box that is worth ſo many thouſand Pounds?

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Why theſe Conſiderations I confeſs made me make a ſeruple of it— and now I think better of it, I will not go.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Why where is the Widdow Mr. Conſul, that you were in in queſt of that was worth a 100000 pound.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Fye, fye, don't mention her; when I enquired into the Buſineſs I found ſhe had but 20000 pound. She took Tobacco, and drunk Brandy, and was no Gentlewoman, and therefore I refuſed her.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p:
Thou art a damnable lying Rogue—I know thou wouldſt take up with an Apple-woman that had but 50 l. Hang it Mr. Sneak, you have brag'd ſo long of your Land in Cornwall that no Body will believe thee. And haſt been fool'd ſo much by every projecting
Codshead, that the whole world laugh at thee, and ſay thou art onely fit for a Chamber among the Fellows of that great Colledg yonder.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: You may ſay your pleaſure Mr. Furniſh.—I'le leave you—But I queſtion not yet to ride in my Coach and ſix Horſes—

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Stay—ſtay, don't go away—here take ſixpence to ſpend at the Coffee-Houſe, for I'm ſure thou haſt no money.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Well well, I will pay you again with Intereſt.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Be ruled by me Mr. Grin, leave your projecting Trade, and keep cloſe to your pimping Trade, 'twill bring you in more money byhalf: Thou art a moſt excellent Pimp—the Ladies are taken with thy Addreſs.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: Well well, Mr. Furniſh—you are full of your jeers— but I am ſtayd for—

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Be not out of the way in the Afternoon, if need be to be bound with me to my Uncle, Mr. O-yes good ſecurity.

sp.speaker: Snea.
sp.p: No no—I'm ſure I'm bound for ſome hundreds already for him—But if one of my Projects hits I ſhall pay all.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Goe thy way for a melancholly, projecting Dreamer, with thy Eſtate in the Clouds—Now is he gone ſneaking to my Uncle Turbulents—I wonder what he does there?—But who comes ſayling here—Oh my Lady Medler: Now for a Dun, and a Rallie—

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Out upon theſe paultry Fields; a Perſon of Quality cannot come to the Doors with a Coach, but muſt alight and foot it. I would not be ſeen thus afoot and alone for any thing— uds ſo, here is Furniſh.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Madam your Servant—what going to my Uncle Turbulents?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: O you are a fine Man never to come at me, are not you?— I have been at leaſt ten times at the Door in my Coach, but you're never within— when your turn's ſerv'd you care not.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: And I think I ſerv'd her turn too, if I am not miſtaken.
O Madam, I'm ſorry for your miſhap, t'other night, going home from my Houſe.

sp.speaker: Lad. Med.
sp.p: Your Men had made my Coach-man drunk

sp.speaker: (Furn.
sp.p: And I think I made her more drunk.)

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: That he could not guide his Coach right, but overthrew it and broke all my Glaſſes. I'm ſure it coſt me Ten Pounds to put my Coach to rights again—You're a fine Man to keep me till three a Clock i'th' morning, wasn't you?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: (Pox on her I could not be rid on her as long as I had one Bottle of Frontineack left) I did not think it ſo late, Madam, but what ſaid Sir Edward — was he not angry?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Angry? would I could ſee that: an he ſhould be angry with me, I'd make my Lord, my Brother angry with him— angry kether? No I call'd him Sweetface a thouſand times, and told him I had been at my Couſens, the Grocer's Wives Labour.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: And he believ'd you?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Why, you don't take him to be ſo unnaturala Beaſt as not to believe his own Wife. But where's my Necklace of Pearl I lent you to take up ſome Money on, did not you promiſe I ſhould have it within 2 days?—

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: A Pox of her Memory, I was afraid of this Dun — Madam, I am about to receive 600 l. this Evening, and then I intend to return it back to your Ladyſhip, with a pair of ſilk Stockings for the uſe of it.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Ay, you are the beſt Man at Promiſes in the World, and the worſt at Performances— Indeed Mr. Furniſh, I muſt have it, Sweet-Face has asked me ſeveral times why I don't wear it— I'll ſtay this Moneth for the 50 l. I lent you.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: (And ſo you're like this 12 Moneths for me; if ſhe has not the Conſcience to pay me for what I do for her, I will have the Conſcience this way to pay my ſelf.)
Indeed Madam, I will repay you all ſhortly, and furniſh your Lady ſhip with what Moneys you ſhall want —
(I muſt put her beſides this Diſcourſe.
Madam, I wonder you can ſpare ſo much time as to come to this End of the Town, conſidering the many Affairs you have in hand, of benefit and weighs — My Lord your Brother helps you to many a Pound.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Tho I ſay it— I have more to do than my Lord Chancellor— and my Lord my Brother has many grand intrigues in hand, I aſſure you; but 'tis a great ſecret, he is now making an Union between the Muſcovite and the Turk, and by his means there will be ſhortly a League, Offenſive and Defenſive, between the Grand Seignior and the Sophy of Perſia; and you will ſee by next Summer, for all the Peace at Nimiguen, all the States in Chriſtendom Confederated againſt the French King— My Lord Politick knows how to play his Cards.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: You are happy, Madam, in being like him— for though you don't make Matches between Kingdoms and States, yet you make many other very conſiderable.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I have made ſome in my time— and to tell you the truth, I was now going to Mr. Turbulent to propoſe a Match between a Kinſman of my Lords and his Daughter Priſ.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: (Dam her— ſhe'll ſpoil all my Deſign) By no means Madam— don't do it.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p:
Why ſo Mr. Furniſh— I think it is no diſparagement to be Related to my Lord my Brother. I tell you Mr. Furniſh,
there is not a Woman in all the Kingdom but would be glad and proud of the Honour.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: No queſtion, Madam— But I have already propos'd a Match for my Couſen Priſcilla, and you will ſpoil all.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Nay if it be ſo, I'm glad I ſpoke of it— I ſhall forbear for your ſake.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But Madam, There is one Match that I know of, which if you could bring about would advantage you at leaſt 10000 l.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Bring it about— I'll warrant you— ne'r fear man, as long as I have my Lord my Brother to back me—prethe who are the perſons?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: 'Tis a difficult buſineſs, and I'm loth-to tell you.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I will know— You ſhall have a ſhare Furniſh— Making of Matches is a good Trade, if it be well handled to get Money on both ſides; but I muſt know who theſe perſons be.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: Why it is between Antichriſt and the Whore of Babylon — 'twould do well if you could bring them together.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Well— well — you jeer me do you? Farewel— but be ſure you remember my Necklace.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: I ſhan't forget it Madam— but not a word of my Couſen Priſcillas Match— I'll not leave you, Madam— I'll ſee you at my Uncle Turbulents.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Fairlove and Mrs. Wellbred.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Your friend yonder is a man of ſence; I like him— but I converſe with ſo wretched a Generation, that I am like one coming out of a dark place, dazled with the light of Sence and Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: He is a plain, downright Gentleman that loves to ſpeak his mind— and I'm afraid he'll beat that Fop Cringe, if we leave them too long together— Therefore my dear Lucy, anſwer me to the Queſtion I ask'd you.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You may be ſure Franc, that I would be glad to be out of this Hell I live in, and dare venture my ſelf with you— and put my Neck in the Yoke of Matrimony — but I tell you, I will alſo bring you the little Fortune my Father has left me, and not give the advantage to my Uncle Turbulent, to cheat me of it— he has a Fanatical Conſcience.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I thought I had taken off that Objection, by telling you the good Fortune that has befallen me of 500 l. a Yeer, by the Death of my Uncle in Norfolk — So that now you cannot object (as you uſe to do) the want of means to live.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: You have indeed Franc been very honeſt in not urging me to Marry before you knew how to keep me like a Gentlewoman, and as many do, to ſatisfie their pleaſure, run themſelves headlong into Miſery— But yet I aſſure you, I will have my Portion before I Marry; tho you are ſo willing to part with it, I am not.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: But you know how averſe he is to me, and that he deſigns you for that Fop Cringe, and what power your Father left with him, ſo that you cannot have your Portion unleſs you Marry as he would have you. Will you therefore ever live in the Purgatory you are in, and permit me ſtill to languiſh for want of your company, or elſe to continue my Walks here among Uſurers, Bawds and Punks, to get now and then a ſight of you?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: No, no, fear it not, I have ſtudied the point, the clauſe of the Will is this, That if my ſaid Ʋncle Turbulent be alive, and compos mentis, that he ſhould have the ſole diſpoſe of me, and that if I married without his conſent, the Chamber of London ſhould not part with my Portion, but it ſhould be at my ſaid Ʋncles diſpoſe — Now if my ſaid Uncle be either dead, or not compos mentis, that clauſe is null, and the Portion, as I take it, is at my own diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fair—
sp.p: You are a cunning Lawyer — but your Uncle is alive— as for the other, compos mentis, that I think he is not— but 'tis not what we think, but what the Law will think in that caſe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, let me alone— I will give you leave to get a Licence againſt to morrow morning, for I have brought my Affairs to ſuch a paſs, that by that time the Law ſhall free me, and he ſhall be either not alive, or not compos mentis.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I confeſs I am gravel'd— but I will not queſtion your ingenuity—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But what ſhall I do with poor Cringe?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Hang him Fop—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I muſt provide him a Wife— my Couſen Priſcilla, as preciſe as ſhe is, is taken with that Fool, and extreamly loves him— I muſt try to get him to Marry her— He is ſo eaſie a Fool that I think I ſhall perſwade him to it for all his pretenſions to me.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: That would do well — ſee he is run away from Friendly— I knew he could not endure him long —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Your moſt humble Servant hey—your Servant Mr. Fairlove— Fore Gad your Friend yonder is the rougheſt man I e're talked with hey—I never ſaw ſuch a ſurly man in my life hey—he does not love talking he ſays—hey—and then I would have read him ſome Verſes hey—and he then grew worſe mad hey—and would have tore 'em hey—then I ſung fa la la la fal la la la, and gad he was ready to kick me hey, he is fit to converſe with no Body but himſelf hey, and ſo I left him hey—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Ay Mr. Cringe, he has his Fits—you muſt not take it ill.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I a'nt ſuch an Aſs hey—but I'le ne're be alone with him again hey—Come Madam Lucy will you go home hey—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Nay I ſhall be angry to if you perſwade the Lady to leave my Company ſo ſoon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come Mr. Cringe, let's ſee thoſe Verſes you would have ſhewn Mr. Friendly—I know they are ſome I ha'nt ſeen yet, and I thank you for thoſe of my Pin.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: They are not finiſhed, yet hey I have onely begun a few hey, which I intend to preſent you when they are finiſhed hey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No no, I'le ſee em now while I'm in the humor, or not at all.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You muſt never deny a Lady any thing.—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Look here, they are but— fore gad they are not yet finiſhed.
Godslid here's the Gentleman does not love Verſes, I dare not read 'em—

div.stage: going to put up the Paper.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come come you ſhall read em—

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I wonder you can fool thus with this City-maggot; Prethee Frank if thou haſt any thing to ſay to the Lady I'le ſtay and beat him going—if not let's goe.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee Friendly be not ſo haſty—Mrs. Lucy has a mind to ſee his Verſes—

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: That any one ſhould take ſuch content in the diverſion of Fools.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Well I'le read if Mr. Friendly will be but freindly hey I think I was witty there hey—You muſt know Madam theſe Verſes are not finiſhed—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why you told us ſo already, Mr. Cringe, let's hear 'em however—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Hem! hem! they are to be directed to you Madam—For the fair hands of the more fair Madam Lucia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I could never tell before which were the faireſt, my hands or my face. Proceed—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Hem! hem! reads—

l.hi: For mighty joys expreſſion in more ſtate
My thoughts Orations did premeditate;
But formal Speeches whiſtling like the Wind,
Oſtentate Wit, not Loyalty of Mind:
Sincerity makes little noiſe, and flies
From hollow hearted, gay Formalities.

sp.p: How do you like it hey—for gad 'tis excellent, to ordinery ſtrains hey —

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: You are no ordinary Puppy I am ſure of it.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir Hey—Hem—hem—ready.

l.hi: But your Averſion now I plainly find
Through the Tranſparent Windows of the Mind;
So a Pellucent Ladies Ivory Skin,
For all her Tiffanies, is ſeen within.

sp.p: Do you mark that hey —'tis good hey—hem! hem! —reads

l.hi: Your honey Speech was ſweet as Woodbine Flower
Of Sugar Lips, too ſoon was ſhut the Door.
Soft as the Wooll of Beaver was your ſtile,
Which makes my raviſh'd Senſe of Hearing ſmile;

q.l: Your ſtroking fingers with May-Morning Dew,

l.hi: My wearied Bodies vigour did renew.
But with delight my Senſe of Seeing ſpies
More amiable Marvels in your Eyes.

sp.speaker: Friend. —
sp.stage: Snatches the Paper and tears it.
sp.p: I can hold no longer, he has wore out my patience— why there's more ſenſe in the chattering of a Monkey.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: He has tore the beſt Copy of Verſes that ever was wrote hey, and that's a bold word hey —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: And ſo it was Mr. Cringe,—But is this all pure City Wit- London Wit— or Moorfields Meditation.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: No, in good Faith 'tis pure York-ſhire Wit; for he has took all this out of the York-ſhire Play called, The Inamouring Girdle.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Godsuckers— I think the Devil is in 'em for ſinding me out— I muſt out-face it.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Let him take it from whence he will, 'tis like himſelf, all Nonſence.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: 'Tis all my own Writing, I proteſt— one thing may be like another hey —

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well, well Cringe, as long as I like it, all is well; I know no body but your ſelf could write ſuch high ſtrains.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: O Madam, I am your moſt humble Servant and Admirer hey— but the Gentleman is a very angry Man hey.

sp.speaker: Enter Mr.
sp.p: Suck-Thumb, habited odly, with his Hat over his Eyes, and walks over the Stage, and goes out.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: What kind of Dumb-ſad is that?— he walks as if he trod on Eggs.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Oh, he is one of the Gang, reſorts much to my Uncle Turbul • nts, ſpeaks hardly 6 words in 6 hours, and then he gapes like Frier Bacon's Brazen Head. He dreams all day, and ſees Viſions at night— and then relates them for the comfort of the Brethren in Tribulation. All he ſpeaks they take for Oracles. He's one of their private Conventicle or Cabal, where they may ſpeak their minds freely.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: A Melancholy Viſionere.

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Whoſe Head travels the Moon, and has lodg'd in all the Inns of the Zodiack and the 7 Stars. He has been beyond the eight Sphere, and brings Embaſſies from thence, his Name is Mr. Abednego Suck-Thumb.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mr. Turbulent will think I'm run away with you, Madam Lucy, hey— ſhall we repair to your Habitation hey?

sp.speaker: Lucy.
sp.p: Well Gentlemen, your Servant— Mr. Fairlove let me ſee you again anon.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Your Servant Gent. — your Servant, your humble Servant Mr. Fairlove. with many ridiculous Cringes and Bows.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Your Servant Mr. Cringe—

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Your Servant Coxcomb—

I admire how ſo well-bred and witty a Gentle-Woman can endure to converſe with thoſe kind of Animals that are about her. I like your Choice Frank, but I don't like your Matrimony. is there no other way— can't you ſave her from drowning, without ſinking your ſelf?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Leave off, I am reſolved— I will deliver her to morrow — To morrow Will. thou ſhalt be at our Wedding.

sp.speaker: Friend.
sp.p: Thou art a kind Servant— Thou'lt deliver her out of Hell, and put thy ſelf into Purgatory.

div.trailer: The End of the Firſt Act.

div.head: THE SCENE. Mr. Turbulent's Houſe.
ACT II.
div.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, Mrs. Turbulent, Priſcilla with a Pipkin of Grewel. Mr. Turbulent in a Night Gown, Caps on his head, a great nightrail flung over his Shoulders— &c.

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: WELL here's ſome Air in this Room— oh! oh! oh! it was a Thundring Emettic — Lord how it work'd, I am wondrous empty.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Here is a whole Pipkin of Plum Grewel for thee— ſhall I give thee ſome of it—

sp.speaker: Turb.
sp.p: No— I bid you get me ſome Egg-Caudle— I will have that firſt, and then the Grewel— Egg-Caudle is comfortable— oh! oh! I am very ſick— Kate I am very ſick, it gripes me yet— It has claw'd me off— it has made me very empty.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter, Mr. Turbulent, and it had been worſe; you muſt be taking Phyſick of ſuch leud French Doctors— This was one of your Nephew Furniſh's helping to, that ſink of Sin, and Son of Perdition, who never did you any good, nor never will— Could not Doctor Pluſh-Coat here at the next Door, have ſerv'd your turn, or Doctor Dodipal one of the Brethren?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Hold your peace— ſpeak not againſt the Doctor, the Phyſick has wrought well— yea very well, both upwards and downwards— why where's this Caudle?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Why Paul, Paul, why Paul—

div.stage: Enter Pollux with a Meſs of Caudle.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Here, I'm coming as faſt as I can: I cannot be here and there and every where. I'm ſure I ſerve for all Employs, your Foot-boy to run of Errands; your Butler to draw your Beer; your Cook to dreſs your Meat, and yet I can't pleaſe you— Sir ſhall I get ready the Turky Eggs?

div.stage: Gives Mr. Tur. the Caudle, who falls to eating.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Ay, get them ready againſt I have eat the Grewel, for I am wondrous empty —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Will you have all ſix?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: All ſix Sirrah?— are ſix ſo much that your Raſcality asks ſo vain a Queſtion?— quickly all ſix—I am very empty— Kate let a Chicken, otherwiſe called a large Pullet, be got ready for my Supper— and ſome more Caudle— I find Caudle is good.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He is become Ravenous; this Phyſick has but only whetted his craving Stomach — Oh theſe Cholerick, Turbulent Men are always great eaters—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Sirrah are not you gone yet about the Eggs?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I'm going— He'll devour me if I ſtay.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis good Caudle— I find it comfortable Kate.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vat is dat you eate dere?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Nothing but Egg Caudle Doctor.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Morbleu— Egg Caudle ſaid you— you be de ſtrange man in de hole Varld— The Debil give you de Phyſic for me— I give de Phyſic to purge de Color and de Melancolly, and you eate de Caudle to make more Color and Melancoly. For vat is dat do you know?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Don't be angry Doctor, I am empty—the Caudle is comfortable—

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: De Caudle is poyſon, and breeds de color ande de me-lan-col-ly, and it vil come to de fourth degree, and den you vil be mad— dat you will get by de Caudle—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You ſha'nt perſwade me out of my Caudle for all that, 'tis comfortable, yea, I find it very comfortable.

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: Me been two, tree, fore day ſtudying and turning over all de Autors to find cure for your diſtemper. Me read Galen, Hippocrates, Sennertus Fuchſius and twenty more, and break me Brane vit de ſtudy, and now you ſpoil all vit de Caudle—cram—cram—cram—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Pray what it his Diſtemper?

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: His diſtemper is de choloric— Melancolly.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: How doſt thou prove that?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You muſt be prating too— what's that to you how he proves it, does Mr. Geoſe-quil prove all he ſays?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Yes, he ſays nothing but what he Proves, and ſo ought he— He ought to make it plain to the Hearers— we do not underſtand what he means by cholleric Melancholly —

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: Maiſtreſs Priſcilla, you be de very learned Voman—but you be troubled alſo very much vid de Melancholly, I can prove dat— and all de Houſe is troubled vid de Melancholly, and all de Varld is troubled vid de melancholly.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thou ſhouldſt tell us how—Thou ſayſt ſo, but that is not enough.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Kate, get me ſome Grewel while the Doctor diſputes— I ſay get me ſome Grewel —

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: If Maiſter Turbulent vil give me de leave I will tel de how all de Varld is troubled vit de Melancolly.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Ay Doctor with all my heart— I may then eat my Grewel in quiet— I can eat and hearken to the Doctor— Kate—the Grewel.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Mark ye me de Melancolly is de general diſeaſe of de hole Varld— all de Varld is troubled vit de Melancolly more or leſs. Democritus did ſtudy de Anatomy of de Melancolly, and one Burton your Country-man did write de great Vollome of de Melancolly; but I vil tell you all de hole Book in fower vards. Dere is de Melancolly— fa la — de Melancolly pick-ſtraw— de Melancolly Dumb-ſad — and de Melancolly ſtark-mad— and dere be all de Melancollicks be Gar—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Very well Doctor, proceed —

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Mark ye me— Dere be de fower ſorts of de Humors wich cauſe de fower ſorts of de Melancollies, dat is de ſanguine or de blood, de Phlegm, de co-lor, and de pure Melancolly or adduſt blood. Mark ye me, dere be alſo, one, two, tree, fower degrees of de Melancolly — De firſt is called de Melancolly only, but if it be not purged away, it vil riſe to de ſecond degree, and den it is called folly; ſo to the tird degree vich is extream folly, and laſtly, to de fowert degree, vich is madneſs.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Methinks the Dector ſpeaks very Learnedly.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Go on Doctor go on—

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vil you never don de eating —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I eat leiſurely— I hearken Doctor — I hear you—

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vel den, Me vil tel ye how de Melancolly diſturbs al Men in de Varld, and is de general diſtemper of de hole Varld. Mark ye me — de ſeat of de Melancolly is de ſpleen vich draws to it de ticker and de groſſer part of de blood, and ven dat intral is full of de aduſt Melancolly blood, and does no vel and rightly d • ſcharge it ſelf, it mixes it ſelf vit de other humors in de body, and ſo diffuſeth it ſelf torow de hole body—Mark ye me.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I do Doctor— I do—

sp.speaker: Quib.
sp.p: Den if de Melancolly mixes it ſelf vit de ſanguine humor, or de blood, it cauſes de Melancolly fa la— it makes de laugh, de ſinging, de caper-ing, de pance-ing—de love— de brisk-neſs— de Poetry— de Verſes, de Love-Letters, de folly, de mimic geſtures, de apiſhneſs— de buffoon and Apiſh Aſſes— for de ſpleen is de ſeat of de laugh, as well as of de ſad and melancolly, but being mixed vit de blood it tickles de ſpleen, and cauſes de laugh hah hah hah— de Frenches my Countrymen are very ſubject to dis ſort of de Melancolly, who are alvais laughing and meery, airy, light, and full of de love—now as dis Melancolly riſes in degrees, it expreſſes it ſelf more or leſs, an example of vich Melancolly, you have daily in Mr. Crings, who comes daily to your houſe, he is, me aſſure you, much troubled vith dis ſort of Melancolly in de tird degree, and if he do not take my Pill for de Melancolly, he vil come to de fowert degree, and den he muſt go to de great Hoſpital, and have a chamber dere to be cured.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Very well Doctor, let us hear the other three Doctor, by that time I ſhall eat up my Grewel—

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
Vel den, if de Melancolly mixes vit de Phlegm it cauſes de Melancolly pick-ſtraw, All de People of de London are very much troubled vit
dis dull and heavy melancholy; dey ſit in their ſhops, and tink, tink, tink, all day long, from morning to de night of noting—all not worth one ſtraw of de little ſheat of dere ſhop, or of de news, buz— buz—buz—dey noting but pick ſtraws all deir life-time—dis cauſes de grave and de full folly de ſtarv'd Aſs—the Politician—the Counſello de Projector, de windmils in de head, de formal buſie body about noting—it makes the falſe hopes and de dull fools—an example of dis melancholly you have in the projecting called Mr. Sneak, who comes often to your houſe; he is troubled vith dis melancolly pic ſtraw, in de tird degree, and very near de forth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: This Doctor I ſay is very learned, I begin to be of his Opinion.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Ay Mother, if he could prove it, but I have not yet heard one Sylogiſm.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Peace—Doctor proceed—as I do

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Vel den de tird ſort of melancholly, is ven de melancholly mixes vith de ſerum of the bloud, and makes it ſtick like puddle water; dis is de pure melancholly, de true atra Bilis black bile, and dis cauſes de dum ſad — he ſits all day vith his hat dus—and his arms acroſs dus—he no ſpeak vards, he tinks altogether, he imagines ſtrange dings, he ſees ſtrange ſights, he tinks of de Dible, of his Cloven-foot, and de horns on his head, he tinks of de Moon, and of de Religion—he ſees Viſions of de Angels, and de ſtrange Beaſts, and de Monſters; dis cauſeth de Propheſie, de Fanatick, de Sects, and de Schiſms, and de Hereticks, de Diviſions, de dark miſts in de ſancy, and in de imagination, and de ſtrange Chimeras, and all de ſtrange deluſions in de varld. An example of dis is the Viſioneer, who often comes hither, one Mr. Abednego Suctum, he is troubled with dis in the fort degree, and is ſit for de Bethlem.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I like not that he ſhould accuſe Brother Suck-Tum

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: Maiſtres Priſcilla is troubled vith dis melancholly in de tird degree, mixed vith de phlegm melancholly, but ſhe may yet be cured; but I tink Mr. Suctum is paſt cure; and all de Elebore in d' Antycyra: vil not give him de perfect cure.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well, Doctor, let us here the fourth.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p:
De fort and de laſt melancholly, is ven it mixes vith de Color; and dis cauſes de melancholly ſtark mad—dis is de ſlava Bilis de yellow bile, or de colorick melancholly dat cauſes all de quarrels in de vorld, and makes de fiting, de Riots, de Routs, de peeviſhneſs, de angrineſs, de beating one another, de diſputing, de Railings, de Revilings, de Treaſons, and de Treaſonable Speeches, de Turbulences, de Rebellions, and oppoſition of de Governours, and de Government, of de Kings and his Laws, and of all unquietneſs in de vorld; Dis is de melancholly Mr. Turbulent which diſturbs you, and which you have in de tird degree, and entring upon the fort, and for which you took my Emettic to purge it out, and to cure you, and now you goe ſpoil all vith
Caudle — me no give you any more Pyſick be gar — you ſhall go to de Bethlem for me —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: What? do you ſay I am mad Varlet as thou art — Hold me not, I will beat the Rogue's Eyes out — Mad — mad — do you give me Phyſick to cure madneſs. Hah! am I mad — mad?

div.stage: Setting down his Grewel and riſing up in great rage Mrs. Turbulent and Priſcilla run and hold him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Be patient Tim — be patient — I think the Caudle has made you cholleric.

sp.speaker: Qui.
sp.p: So now you vil ſe de effects off de Caudle, and off de yellow bile, de Colore — I ſay Maiſtre Turbulent you are mad, and vil be mad, and muſt go to de Betlem for de cure — and ſo fare de vel.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Rogue, Dog, Raſcal, Knave, does he come here to abuſe me.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thou wilt do thy ſelf hurt to ſtrain thy ſelf after thy Phyſick — thou ſhouldeſt not be angry —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Sawcineſs, what! muſt you be prating too with your thees and thous? —
Let me alone —

div.stage: offers to ſtrike her, is held by Mrs. Turbul.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I begin to be of the Doctors mind without a Syllogiſm; I think this is demonſtration.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Good Tim. be not ſo angry — and Turbulent —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I will be angry — I will be Turbulent — and I'll make ye all know your ſelves, and that I have the Spirit of Government, I will be angry you ſhall ſee —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Turb.
sp.p: I think he's quite Mad —

div.stage: Mrs. Tur. and Priſ. run rut, Mr. Turb. runs after them.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I think your Uncle is mad within, his Wife and his Daughter can hardly hold him: will you go in and ſee to pacifie him — your Doctor Quibus has made him mad in telling him he would be mad — They are all together by the Ears, go in and part 'em.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Not I — the Divil part 'em for me — I intend to make 'em madder Pol. before night, for I intend to make him drunk —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Not now he has taken Phyſick —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Yes to chooſe — I hope the Doctor has purged away ſome of his Choler — good Pol. when you ſee the Coaſt clear give my Uncle this Note from me — be ſure you do not let my Aunt ſee it, nor any body elſe — be very private good Pol. — There's ſomething for thee —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He ſhall he ſure to have it. But I can't imagine how you'll get forth — there is to be a private meeting by and by —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that — I know I have a Charm in the Note — Proſit — Advantage and Wine of free coſt, that will bring him to me for all his Phyſick and his private Meeting — tho he were in the midſt of his Railing, which he loves next to his Guts and Money. But be ſure Pol. to have a care that my Aunt ſee you not give him the Note —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I warrant you — you know I am truſty —
(Calling within, Why Paul—Paul—Paul —) You had beſt ſow me to your Waſt-Band, here's a deal of calling and bawling upon Paul.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why do they call thee Paul?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: O! they have only turn'd my Heathen and Prophane Name, as they call it, of Pollux to Paul — after they had taken me I was like to have been diſcharged when they heard my Name was Pollux — hark, they call again — I muſt ſee what's the matter —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: O Mr. Furniſh am I ſo happy as to meet you here! What have I done to you that you come not near my Shop — is not Holborn in your way never? —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis a dangerous Hill Mrs. Sly — I don't love to go that way.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: You us'd to call often upon me when you went to your Taylors Mr. Snipwel in Fullers Rents — they ſay Mr. Furniſh, you are very kind to his Wife — I proteſt I cannot but wonder you are ſo kind to an oldiſh Woman, as ſhe is. —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am kind to all, Mrs. Sly, old and young, fair and foul, all's one to me, when I'm in the humor; I have too much buſineſs to ſtand picking and chooſing of Faces when I ſhould need 'em —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: When ſhall you receive money Mr. Furniſh, my Chicken bid me to call upon you for the 40 s. for Oyl, and Anchovies, and Olives and Capers — it has been now above a Twelve Moneth on the Book —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Pox on her, I thought I had paid her ſufficiently for that Score, and that ſhe would not have the impudence to have asked me for this poor Sum — what will this World grow to at laſt.) Faith Mrs. Sly, I had quite forgot — I will call upon you one day or other — (I'll be even with this Jade for offering to ask me for Money.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Do Mr. Furniſh — you ſhall be heartiſy welcome.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But hark you Mrs. Sly — I have been often told of your Huſbands railing againſt the Times and the Government, openly in his Shop, as if behind the Counter were a Priviledge-place, ſpeaks and talks at a ſtrange rate of Railing — I tell you on't for your good Mrs. Sly — I heard it talkt of — I fear you'll be informed againſt — and try'd upon the Statute of Scandalum Magnatum.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Cannot Men ſpeak in their own Houſes but they muſt be troubled for it — is it not a very wicked Age — a dangerous time —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But why cannot you let the times alone, Mrs. Sly, and follow your Vocations and your Meetings, and let the King and his Councillors alone — what is that to your Oyl and the Olives, or to the Muſtard and Salt — I tell you out of kindneſs, does it bring in any proſit? —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p:
Yes by it we are known to the Godly, and it is as good as
a Sign at the Door — my Shop is never empty — my Husband is an honeſt man —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay, this is ſomething to the purpoſe, if you gain by railing — but for your husbands honeſty pray Mrs. Sly brag not of that; for the People ſay he is a great Wencher.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly,
sp.p: Out upon them — He a Wencher — I don't find he is ſo able — they bely him fearfully —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis true enough Mrs. Sly — He ſpends abroad to my knowledge, which makes him ſo weak at home: You don't know what a ſly man he is.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Do not ſcandalize my Chicken — He would not do ſuch a thing for the whole World.

sp.speaker: (Fur.
sp.p: Nor you neither.)

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: He never goes out but to Meetings, I aſſure you. He haunts no ill places — not he — as I know on.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: As you know on — Why, do you think he'll let you know on't? when you think he is hearing Mr. Thumper and Mr. Long-Lungs, he is in diſguiſe picking up Wenches in Moor-fields.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Well Mr. Furniſh, You may talk, but he is no ſuch manner of Man —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay if you won't believe me, will you believe your own eyes — leave but the Shop to night, and dreſs your ſelf up very modiſhly, put ſome Patches on thoſe Pimples, and a Vizard Mask o're the face, and do you walk in the dark of the Evening this night, in the lower Walk, near the Old-Bedlam, and you ſhall ſee this preciſe. Husband of yours, whom you think ſo devotedly hearing Mr. Long-Lungs, pick you up, and carry you to a Bawdy-Houſe.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: I'll give you a good Diſh of Anchovis if it be ſo: I proteſt I'll try — But I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Try Mrs. Sly, and call me a thouſand Rogues if it be not ſo — but be ſure you go into the Popes-Head Tavern, and I'll be there to aſſiſt you —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: And ſo I will — I'll ſee if he ſpeaks truth.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: How now Chicken, with whom have you left the Shop — had not you patience to ſtay till I came home? —

sp.speaker: Rab. Sly.
sp.p: I left the Shop to be looked too by Brother Suck-Thumb, he's very honeſt, and I promiſed to ſend thee to him Chicken, that he may come to Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Out upon't, leave Mr. Ahednego Suck-Thumb in the Shop, he's got into another World by this — out upon't, he's looking in the Moon, not to the Shop — (But I'll watch your water I'll warrant you —

sp.speaker: Rab. Sly.
sp.p: Oh! it is the beſt and moſt diligent Wife as ever man had, Mr. Furniſh — ſhe's ſo careful of her Shop ſhe's worth Gold — But Mr. Furniſh, I think you have forgot the little debt you owe me for Commodities?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Pox on him, he's dunning me too, but I'll ſtop his moutn —) I will pay it ſhortly Mr. Sly, I had forgot it indeed; but Mr. Sly, I hear a very ill report of your Wife, that ſhe is continually railing againſt the Court-Ladies, and calls Weſtminſter Sodom and Babel, preaches Lectures behind the Counter againſt Patches and Painting, and againſt the Pride and the Vanity of the Ladies of the other end of the Town — and calls her betters Jezabels and Strumpets — Mr. Sly, I am afraid ſhe will be inform'd againſt —

sp.speaker: Rab. Sly.
sp.p: Alas poor Chicken! — ſhe thinks no hurt, ſhe does it out of pure zeal — Oh the iniquity of the times! — they are very enormous times truly Mr. Furniſh.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay indeed, Mr. Sly, ſo they are, for People to pretend to Religion and have none, to go to Meetings and cheat at home, to ſpeak againſt Swearing and Lye all day long, to Rail againſt Whoredom openly, and Kiſs a Siſter in private — very enormous times Mr. Sly —

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Nay, they are the Wicked that do ſo.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay, they are the pretended ſanctified Brethren that do ſo.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Why do you accuſe the good People ſo falſly? do you think they are like you?

sp.speaker: Fur,
sp.p: No Mr. Sly, I do that openly which you do privately, your Conſcience knows that — but it is an abomination, yea a very great abomination and vileneſs in me, but in you 'tis but a backſliding, a ſlip and frailty of Nature.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Your Uncle will not own you in theſe accuſations — I ſhall let him know you are of a vile ſpirit —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: In the mean time I will let you know that your dear Chicken knows how to be even with you Mr. Sly.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Even with me! for what?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Oh, Oh — you know for what: ſhe knows when to take her times — when you are hearing Mr. Windy and Mr. Little-ſence, ſhe knows how then to take a turn in Moor-fields, or ſo.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Oh! this is intollerable — don't ſcandalize my Chicken ſo, you had not beſt —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why this 'tis to be incredulous — believe your own eyes, you are to go to the Meeting to night — when ſhe thinks you faſt, and you ſuppoſe her in the Shop, you may ſind her here walking in the lower Walk by the Popes-Head Tavern — and will take a Collation or ſo.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: Can this be true Mr. Furniſh, (And why mayn't ſhe tranſgreſs as well as I? —) I have a good mind to be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis true as I tell you, I know thoſe who have met her dreſt up in her Sunday-Cloathes, perfum'd with Roſe-Cakes, a flaunting Tower on her head, and all thoſe ſhining Pimples in her face, hidden under black Patches, a yellow Hood, and a Vizard to keep her ſelf unknown — And in this very dreſs, if you pleaſe, you may meet her this night about twilight.

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: I would willingly ſatisfie my ſelf-ſure Chicken does not ſerve me ſo.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come to met at the Popes-Head Tavern, and I'll furniſh you with a Wigg, Hat and Campain Coat turn'd up with blew, ſo that ſhe may not know you — and you ſhall pick her up your ſelf, and bring her to the Tavern and be convinc'd that I tell you no lye —

sp.speaker: Rab.
sp.p: And I will — 'tis a buſineſs of much concern — if it be ſo, I find her Nature is frail, and ſhe is not yet ſo perfect as I took her to be. Well Mr. Furniſh, I'll meet you at the time — but I can't believe that Chicken is falſe to me. I'll go into Mr. Turbulent —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: So he's gone to exerciſe his Lungs with my Uncle Turbulent, to Rail againſt the Government, and the abominable Prophanation of the Times, and to ſpeak Treaſon in their little private Conventicle — He's a ſweet Saint, but I hope to be even with him. Enter Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I ſee this is a dangerous place for me to enter into, here's dun after dun — I can't ſhun him —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mr. Furniſh hey, your moſt humble Servant Mr. Furniſh, 'tis a rare thing to ſee you hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why ſo Mr Cringe, I am not ſuch a Monſter.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, but you are never at home — I have been at your houſe 40 times hey, and can never meet with you hey — I thought you had been a man of your word hey — did not you promiſe me the 100 Pound you owe me hey — without ſail at Chriſtmaſs laſt hey — and now it is July hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (I muſt put him beſides this diſcourſe) If you call on me to morrow or next day Mr Cringe, I will give you a Bill upon a Banker in Lumbard Street; but pray Mr. Cringe, how goes ſquares between my Cozen Lucia and you — when are you to be Married Man —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why Mr. Furniſh, 'tis a ſecret — but I'll tell you, it is ſooner than ſhe thinks for hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That's pretty, Marry and ſhe not know it — what, you have got another Miſs —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, I have got a Licence ready, and Mr. Turbulent has promiſed I ſhall be married to her to morrow hey, He'll make her conſent hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But do you think ſhe loves you Mr. Cringe?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Oh yes, ſhe loves me hugely hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Then you have the Art of Courtſhip — ſhe's witty —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: The Art of Courtſhip hey — I court her after the beſt and neweſt way of Courtſhip hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why in brave Heroick Verſe — hey — juſt as the great Heroes do in the Play-Houſe hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Then I ſee Mr. Cringe, you ſteal privately to Plays in the Afternoon, after you have been at a Meeting in the Morning.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I go only to ſee Civil, Heroic Plays hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Indeed that is a moſt excellent faſhionable way of making Love. I'll tell you there is a Gentleman that I know, who is about to put all Cook upon Littleton into Heroicks, not blank Verſe but Rimes, and would have engaged me to have ſpoken to my Lady Medler to get an order that the Lawyers ſhould plead in Verſe — why I think they might as well go to Law in Rime, as make Love in Rime, 'twould make the Lawyers the more ſatyrical.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: That would be excellent. Cook hey! I'll have that Cook when it comes out hey.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But Mr. Cringe, ſhan't I ſee ſome of your Poetry —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I have a Copy of Verſes here, but they are not finiſhed hey, and tho I ſay it, they are the beſt Heroicks that ever were wrote hey, and that's a bold word hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I hope they are not long — I do not love long Stories in Verſe.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: No, they are but a few hey — but you may judge by them, 'tis a Dialogue between Mrs. Lucia and my ſelf hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: A Dialogue: Oh! I love diſcourſing in Verſe, 'tis excellent — come read it —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: You muſt know hey, that Mrs. Lucia in a croſs fit hey, would have had me not to love her hey — and you ſhall ſee how I have anſwered her hey — I proteſt in as high ſtraines as ever were writ hey.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Pox on your preambles; read 'em —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Nay, I muſt make you underſtand hey — look ye hey, Lu. Well. — ſtands for Lucia Well-bred; and Fin. Crin. for Finical Cringe hey — now mark ye — Fin. Crin. begins — hem — Reads
Loves fire within me does ſo fiercely glow,
My heart flames out in Sacrifice to you,
Your pity which can never do you harm,
Will keep you from conſuming like a Charm — Mark that hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Very good — a high ſtrain.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Now Lu. Well — replies — hem —
If common pity will your pain relieve
That is an Alms I'll not refuſe to give,
But could I Sir, reſemble your deſires,
In anſwering them with the like ſcorching fires;
We our own executioners ſhould prove,
And burn up one another with our love.?
Mark that hey — is it not excellent hey?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: By my Faith (as Ben Johnſon ſays) a very high vapour, 'tis a ſtrain beyond Ela Man —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Hem — hem — now Fin. Crin. replies,
The flame of Love no water can aſſwage,
It makes it blaze and roar with fierce and rage.
Now Lu Well. — again — mark —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I do — (that you are a Ninny)

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
'Tis 'cauſe you don't —
Fling on freſh Buckets at a faſter rate,
A cloſe ſupply its fury will abate —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: She gives you good Counſel Mr. Cringe — but what's that half Verſe, for with a long ſcratch was your Muſe jaded —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis the ſaſhion to write ſo — in imitation of Virgil —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Whether there be any reaſon for it or no —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Prethe let me go on — you'll forget the ſenſe hey, Mark how I anſwer hey, now Fin. Crin. again,
I'm quite tyr'd out, juſt like an o'retyr'd Peaſt
That's ſinking, being with too much weight oppreſt.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Alas poor weary Aſs — an excellent Simile —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Nay, Mark what Lu. Well. ſays —
Then you ſhould out aloud for ſuccour cry —
To eaſe you in this ſad neceſſity.
Then Fin. Crin. replies with a ſmart Repartee hey —
Oh! 'tis you only that can ſuccour give,
And reaching out to death can make me live.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That's beyond my comprehenſiou.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mark again —Lu. Well. — Speak then —

sp.speaker: Fur.
