sp.p: Why what have you been doing all this while, that ſhe bids you ſpeak now? have you been talking all this while Incognito?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p:
Pray Mark, You are ſo Critical — hey
Speak then, And you ſhall ſee that I will prove
So kind, to give you anything — but Love —

Do'ye Mark that long Pauſe hey, 'tis fine that, and modiſh, as ſhe had granted me all things, and then to daſh it all with a But again, But Love — hey is not that fine — But then Mark how I anſwer. Fin. Crin. —
But Love — Mark the long pauſe again hey

l.hi: But love — And that's the only thing I crave,
Without it I were better in my grave.

lg.l: Is not that an excellent concluſion — hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why I thought you ſaid you had not concluded them.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I do intend to make it longer hey, but for the preſent hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But for the preſent — they are long enough of Conſcience, but I muſt tell you Mr. Cringe, that you are a very Plagiary, and have ſtole this moſt excellent Dialogue out of a Play eall'd Loves Triumph — I ſee you deal in Plays as well as Sermons Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I proteſt I am the moſt unfortunate man alive Mr. Furniſh, 'tis a very Thieviſh Age, for that Author ſtole 'em from me hey — or elſe our fancies jumpt together hey —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It may be ſo Mr. Cringe — well I muſt take my leave of you —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Pray don't ſpeak of theſe Verſes to Mrs Lucia hey — I will ſurpriſe her with 'em hey — your Servant Mr. Furniſh, your very humble Servant —

div.stage: with many fooliſh and antick bows — Exit.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Go thy ways for a ſilly, finical, conventicling, verſifying Ninnehammer.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Cozen Lucia — how is't? God give you joy Couz, I hear you are to be married to morrow.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: (How the Devil came he to know that) Yes — ſo I am to day — and will be till I am married; who told you ſo?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Your own dear Love —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: (Sure he was not ſo impudent) My Love who's that?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Why he that's to marry you to morrow, Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: (Oh is it there, I had like to have committed a miſtake) that's ſuddenly indeed, and I know nothing of it.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis a Secret Couz: but you ſee I make none of it to you — the Fop has got a Licence ready, and my Uncle has promiſed him to morrow, but I think you have more wit than to have ſuch a Ninny.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thank you Cozen Furniſh for this diſcovery, I ſee he drives hard, but I will prevent it — I muſt take another courſe with this Coxcomb, and play the fool with him no longer.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Did not you tell me Couz. that you would let me ſee my Uncles Armour of Brown Paper — But you are a Wag, and put it upon him —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: In truth Couzen Furniſh I told you no lye, for he ſpoyl'd me three Silver Thimbles in making it, and ſpent me 6 d. in Needles — He work'd harder than a Taylor before Eaſter at it, for 6 Weeks lock'd up cloſe in the Garrat, it is his own handy work every ſtitch on't, I'll aſſure you —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But what is it for?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You know he is terribly affraid of being laid up, or ſent to Priſon, for his Treaſonable Speeches, his guilty Conſcience tells him he deſerves it, and though there's no danger at all, he and his Viſioner has fram'd ſuch dreadful fancies in their Heads, that he is afraid of his own ſhadow, and every noiſe of the Car Men in the Street makes him fear a Maſſacre, or a Purſevant, and I know not what melancholly Chimera's.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But could he not have bought him Arms.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh no — His Covetouſneſs would not let him do that — beſides he was affraid he ſhould have been ſuſpected for a Plotter, if Arms had been found in his Houſe.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: But brown Paper would be but ſmall defence to either Sword or Bullet.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I aſſure you he has made it Piſtol Proof very near, and as to a Sword 'tis impenetrable.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Fore Gad I long to ſee theſe famous Arms.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And that you ſhall at night, and him in 'em, if you will but diſguiſe your ſelf like a Purſevant, or an Officer of the Guards, and get two or three Red Coates, and Muſquets and Bandeleers, with which we'll furniſh Hangby, Pol and one or two more, like Souldiers — and let me alone to fright him into his poſture —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Faith, I have a deſign upon him, before night, but this pleaſes me ſo well, that I won't miſs it — in the mean time Couz farewel — you ſhall ſee me at night —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well Pol. what ſays Doctor Quibus?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: He ſays he will be with you inſtantly, and ſwears Morb •• u, the whole Houſe is mad beſides your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's well — 'Tis to prove 'em mad I ſend for him — didſt get the Certificate drawn fair that I ſcribl'd o're —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes, there 'tis —

This is to Certify all whom it may concern, That Mr. Timothy Turbulent now dwelling in the lower Square in Moor-fields is not Compos mentis, but is de' ſtraught of his Senſes, and fit for to be placed in the Charitable Hoſpital of Bethlem for Cure.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I think 'tis well enough, this I'm ſure Dr. Quibus will ſign to, and for a Guinny I know I can have Doctor Pluſh's Hand.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay, and that you and all the Houſe are mad too for another Guinny.

div.stage: Enter Suck-Thumb, walking on the Stage with his Hat over his Eyes and Arms acroſs.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Peace be unto yee —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And to you alſo — There goes the Seer — do they meet to day Pol —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ay — ay — they are going to exerciſe; Mr. Rahſheca is there already — But I ſhall ſhorten their Meeting by and by — I'le ſpoil it —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh, I have a Note from Mr. Furniſh to fetch him to the Popes Head-Tavern — His good, dear Nephew knows how to charm him — But my old Mrs. muſt not know on't —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But I'le tell her on't, and ſend her like an Harpie among 'um — when they are in the midſt of their ſport —

div.stage: Enter Cringe —ſinging fal la la la

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh here's my finical fa — la — I'le make him change his Note inſlantly — I muſt leave fooling with this Fool.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: [with many antick Ducks and Cringes] your Servant Madam Lucia, I kiſs your fair hands hey — Mr. Turbuleut is going to be buſie hey, and ſo I left him hey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And ſo am I — therefore pray leave me too —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I am not ſo ill-bred Madam Lucia hey — what to leave a fair Lady hey, and my Mrs. hey.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Cringe take notice that I leave you now for altogether; and that the Farce between us is ended: I am quite tyred with your Puppetplay, and I will have no more on't.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I don't underſtand you Madam Lucia hey —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Then I'le make you underſtand me hey — mark me, if from this inſtant you ever come to offer me any of the paultry Heroicks, or to make love to me, or to ſpeak, ſay, or pretend, that I am your Miſtreſs, oroffer ſo much as by dumb ſhow, or with your grimaces to make any Court to me: If I can not beat thee my ſelf, I will have thee ſoundly lambaſted, and well-favourdly kicked by ſome body elſe — do you underſtand me now.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: This is very plain hey — you are but in jeſt ſure hey —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You had not beſt put it to the Tryal — youl find I am in earneſt — and that I tell you this in true, keen, and downright Iambicks, which is better than all your ſilly Heroicks.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Umh — this is tart hey — quite forſake me hey —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, for rll you have got a Licenſe hey —

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: (Oh this wicked Mr. Furniſh has told her of the Licenſe and ſpoiled all.)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
Come I'le adviſe you for old acquaintance ſake, ſince you have been at the charge of taking out a Licence, tis but ſcraping out my name Lucia Well-bred, and putting in my Couſin Priſcilla Turbulent, and all will be well again. She loves you, and there is 500 l. in Mr. Furniſhes hand put out for her to my knowledg — Go I ſay, Court her, and get her; the buſineſs is half done already — for I ſwear to you Mr. Cringe, I would ſooner loſe all my
portion, and let my Uncle Turhulent take it, than be married to ſuch a ſimple, nonſenſical, finical Aſs as you are.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: This is very pla • n Mrs. Well-bred — hey —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis very true Mr. Cringe — (oh here ſhe comes, if I could make theſe Extreams meet 'twould be excellent, and out of their diſagreement frame an harmonious ſound I ſhould be a ſhee-Orpheus.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: (I have a good mind to Court Mrs. Priſcilla in very ſpight — that may make her come about hey —)

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Couſin Priſcilla I have been ſpeaking a good word for you to Mr. Cringe here — he ſays he loves you very much — and I know you love him, he has many good parts: why ſhould you not know one another better — Long Courtſhips, out of faſhion — come Mr Cringe ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: And ſo I will hey — (I don't care a pin for you Mr. Lucia fa la la la fal la la ly do you think I doted on you To Mrs Lucy aſide ſings hey — you are miſtaken hey, and I will have Mrs. Priſcilla, and ſhe ſhall have your Portion hey — how do you like that they —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ay, ay, if you can get it —

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: (aſide) I have a great fancy and deſire for this man. I like his fine, airy humour; it will do well to mix with my heavy temper. I had beſt provide for my ſelf whileſt I may.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Do you love me Mrs. Priſcilla — hey

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt ſo.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: But I would have you ſay ſo — hey —

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Plainly if it would do thee any good to know it; verily I have a kindneſs for thee.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: That is well hey — and I will alſo be kind to you from this time forth — hey

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I (I have ſoon made an end of the buſineſs hey, this is to the purpoſe hey. I can round, round, like a horſe in a Mill with Mrs. Lucia hey, and am now where juſt where I began hey — A ſig for Mrs. Lucia — I'le get Mrs. Priſcilla in earneſt if ſhe will but love Heroicks —)

sp.speaker: Crin,
sp.p: But Mrs. Priſcilla ſhall I ſhew you ſome Verſes — won't you love Verſes —)

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: They are very vain and abomianble, and uſed only among the prefane; they ſtink in the Noſtrils of the Righteous.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mrs. Priſcilla we ſhall never agree if you will not let me write Heroicks, I ſhall never marry you.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I had beſt yield to him till I am married, and then I may convert him from that Pagan Trick of Verſifying.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I will write Hymns and Lamentations.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thou ſayeſt well — plainly that will be very agreable to my diſpenſation — ha mayeſt write Hymns of Lamentation whilſt the good people are under perſecution.
(Calling within Priſ. Priſ. why Priſ.) My mother calleth, Finical Cringe, I ſhall be paſſing, but I am thine in the Love.

sp.speaker: Grin.
sp.p: So, I have made a ſhort hand of it hey — I ſhall get Mr. Turbulent's Daughter, and Mrs. Lucia's Portion, for ſhe'll Marry Mr. Fairlove hey, and then her Uncle won't give her a Groar hey— and ſo I ſhall have all— for ho has no body elſe to give it to hey—a fig for Mrs. Lucia, hey, fal la la la fa la la fa la—

div.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, Sly, Suck-Thumb and Pollux.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Where is your Miſtreſs Paul?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: In her Chamber Sir.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: What is ſhe doing?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Cutting her Cornes.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Then ſhe intends to go abroad to night—where is my daughter?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: In her Chamber, reading a piece of Ariſtotle's Logick, call'd Problems, or hard Queſtions

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Where is my Neece?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: She is in her Chamber at work.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: They are all well employ'd—go Sirrah, ſee that the Doors be lock'd faſt and bolted, let the outer Windows be ſhut up, that the ſound of the Voice may not go forth—and be ſure to ſtand at the Door that no body interrupt us, and give us notice if any come near—be you on your watch Sirrah—'tis dangerous times friends, and 'tis wiſdom to be cautious. Brother Suck-Thumb ſet down— Exit Pol. Come ſet down, this is the moſt private Room in the Houſe we may ſpeak free,— They ſet Suck. Thumb pulls his Hat over his eyes, and puts his thumb • n his mouth, leaning his • lbow upon his other arm Are not theſe ſad times Brother Rabſheka, that we muſt skulk thus in holes and corners— Oh the good times of Nerva, when every one might think what he pleaſed, and ſpeak what he thought and never be queſtioned for't, oh that was a gracious Heathen Emperor—

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Or the good times of the Rump, when any one might rail againſt Kingly Government, and the idols of Monarcy, without check or controul. I tell you Brother Turbulent, it is a great tribulation to have ones zeal quenched—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Ay Brother, ſo that we are fain to whiſper in the Cloſet, when we ſhould cry on the houſe-tops

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Whilſt the Nimrods, the Nebuchadnezzars, the Balſhazers, and the oppreſſing Pharaohs ride in their Chariots, and on their Horſes.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Whilſt the Jezabels and the Athalias run about like wild Colts ſnuffing up the Wind.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And yet we muſt be ſilent and our mouths muſt be muzzled, that we may not bray againſt thoſe ſad abominations— But I will ſpeak, and I muſt ſpeak, and I cannot but ſpeak againſt Monarchy, which is the very tail of the Beaſt, that ariſes up with ſeven heads out of the Bottomleſs Pit.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis the Idol of the World and ought to be pull'd down, and laid in the Duſt—It muſt be overturn'd—overturn'd—overturn'd—

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: For it permits the wicked and abominable men to do what is good in their own eyes— and ſuppreſſes the fiery zeal, and the zealous fury of thoſe who ſtand up for Reformation.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And ſuffers the gathering together of Minſtrels, and the noiſe of the Flutes, and the tinkling Cymbals in the Streets.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And the Mor is dancers and the Rope-Dancers, the Puppet-Plays—the Bull-bating, the Bear-bating, the Horſe-Races, and the Cards, and the Dice, oh abominable!

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And the Players of Interludes, and the Men and the Women ſingers.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: But Babylon muſt fall—muſt tumble, muſt be pulled down—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And it ſhall fall, and it ſhall tumble, and it ſhall be pulled down— Suck-Thumb groans once or twice. peace brother Suck-Thumb has ſeen a Viſion, he is about to ſpeak— Brother Abednego what haſt thou ſeen—

div.stage: He lifts up his Hat gravely.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I was carried out of this carnal body into the World in the Moon and there I beheld a great Tree, whoſe Branches overſpread the face of the earth. On the top of this Tree ſat an Eagle, and a Crown upon his Head— And there came a mighty Dragon out of a River, running 〈◊〉 the foot of this Tree and Fire came out at his mouth, and he devoured the Tree, and the Eagle thereon.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh wonderful! haſt thou the interpretation of this Viſion given to thee?—

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Not yet— it may be revealed—

div.stage: Enter Pollux gives Mr. Turbulent a Note, he goes aſide and reads.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis from my Nephew Furniſh, I hope he his got ſome money for me—

body.p: I muſt needs ſpeak with you about a very great concern and advantage to you. I am at the Popes-Head-Tavern, near your houſe • here I have • ot ready a Pottle of butter'd Sack, becauſe I heard you had taken Phyſick; make • aſt, an • l • t not my Aunt know of it.

sp.p: Friends I have a very great conce • n tha • calls me away at this time but we will meet again—

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: And I have alſo at this time ſo … e • traordinary buſineſs to go to Mr. Furniſh.

sp.speaker: Suc •
sp.p: Peace be with you— I ſhall retire into the ſilence and wait—

div.trailer: The End of the Second ACT.

div.head: The Third Act.
The Scene a Tavern.
div.stage: Enter Furniſh and Hangby dreſs'd, with a broad brimm'd Hat, cropt Hair, little Band, broad skirted Doublet, cloſe knee'd Breeches, a little black Cloak, faced down, &c.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: WHy, thou art dreſs'd in Quirpo— and ſo metamorphozed, that no body can know thee—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: The right Cut of an Amſterdam Brother —

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.p: But you muſt alter your Voice —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I have the right twang of the Noſe — let me alone for both whine and goggle.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Thou art a pure Rogue — what ſhall your name be?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Oh! Peregrine Pricket —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: It ſounds well — this Uncle of mine is at his Exerciſe, he'll hardly be here yet this hour.

div.p: Oh, here's Grin Sneak, he won't know you in this Dreſs, — let's ſport with the Fool a while.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Are you buſie Mr. Furniſh? —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No Grin. — (Aſide to Sneak) Oh Sirrah, I have met with one of the rareſt Fellows in the World for Projects; — but he is a Stranger, and you may make your ſelf by him — he wants ſome body to promote his Buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Say you ſo — let me alone for that — you know my Lady Medler is my true Friend —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Peregrine Pricket, pray know this Gentleman, Sir — he is of my Acquaintance — you'll find him a very ingenious Man, and one who is a great Vertuoſo, and lover of Rarities — one that has ſpent his whole Life in ſinding out rare Inventions.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: You give him a friendly Character — Sir, your humble Servant — I am blunt, Sir, and a Traveller.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Your Servant Sir, I ſhall be happy in the Acquaintance of ſuch an ingenious man, as I underſtand you are: I have made it my buſineſs Sir, to find out many things for the good of the Commonwealth — But of all, I am pleas'd with one thing that I am now undertaking, that will make England happy, and will cauſe the Act of Burying in Woollen to be repealed.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That would do well, and be a great eaſe to the Heart of many an old Woman, who weeps and laments o're her lace Cut-work Smock, that has been laid up in Lavender for fifty years, to be buried in, and now muſt be wrapt in Woollen.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Indeed that is a beneficial Project — but I have one that will be much more beneficial to my ſelf, and to all the Land of England, Scotland and Ireland — I can take a Partner in with me; and yet upon the dividend reſerve 20000 pounds to my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: (— Oh God, this is a rare Fellow — I will get in with him—) Mr. Pricket (I think Mr. Furniſh calls you) pray let us confer Notes together over a glaſs of Wine — Knocks —

div.p: Sirrah, fetch a Bottle of the beſt Claret —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Jack, if my Uncle Turbulent comes to enquire for me, give me notice —

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: This Rogue has not Money to pay for this Bottle of Wine, and yet the joy of meeting this Projector, has put him into a Rapture, and given him ſome Confidence — who elſe is the ſneaking'ſt Puppy in the World —

div.p: Well Gentlemen, ſit down, and be plain with one another like friends.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I ſhall not be thy Servant — look you here Sir, do you ſee this Lock of curious fine Flax, of which they may make Siſters Thread — and yet this Flax is made of the courſeſt Hemp in England —

div.stage: Pulls out a Lock of fine Flax, wrapt up in a Sheet of Paper.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, 'tis very fine — but when I was in Flanders, I met with a certain Dutchman, that made juſt ſuch out of Nettle Stalks, and was crying an hundred pound weight of Nettle-Seed, to ſow all the Fields about Bruges, of which he intended to make the fineſt ſort of Cambricks —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: That was extraordinary — of this Sir, I intend to make fine Holland, and by which I ſhall get de claro, ſixty pound a week, and ſo improve the Manufacture of Linnen in England that it ſhall be ſo plentiful within a few Years, that they ſhall be glad to bury it again under ground.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Peregrine, I think now he will out-do you —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Pray Sir, I confeſs he goes beyond me in Manufactures; but I aſſure you, I can go beyond him, or any man elſe at the Handycraft Trade. I have made a Wimble to bore Hairs, which I can do ſo exactly, by the help of a Microſcope, that it cauſed the great Admiration of ſeveral Vertuoſo's

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But of what uſe can that be? I love things that are beneficial to a Commonwealth.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Oh Sir, they are to make treble Flagellets for Ladies, that they may not ſpoil their mouths with the great ones —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But this is but of little benefit to your ſelf — mine will bring me in 60 l. a week —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p:
That I confeſs was by the by; but my great Project that
will make us both rich, and which I have been this 17 years about, is an admirable Flea-trap, a Benefit the Commonwealth never yet received from all the Vertuoſo's.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But the Profit as to us ſtill? —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I'll make it plain to you — there are ſo many thouſand Houſes in England, now every Houſe ſhall have one of theſe Traps for 1 s. a year, which I will be bound to furniſh them with; now what Family in England would not be glad to have ſuch a Trap, to catch all their Fleas? They would think it the beſt ſhilling that ever was given in their Lives, and pay it willinglier than Hearth-money—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: 'Fore God, 'tis a rare Invention, and exceeding beneficial! but have you made Tryal of it?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Yes—Yes— I have a Compoſt of a ſtrange faculty, which will draw all the Fleas in the Houſe into the Trap — I made Tryal of it the other day for a Wager, and enticed a Flea out of a Ladies warm Boſom, which a Gentleman had made a Copy of Verſes on—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: That was admirable— I will ſpeak to my Lady Medlar to get a Patent, that none ſhall make of theſe Traps for ſeven years but your ſelf.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Why, that's it I would have, and judge you if there be but 500000 Houſes in England (as there are the Lord knows how many more) and that we have twelve pence a Houſe yearly, to what a brave Eſtate it will amount; and this alſo may be got for Scotland and Ireland, perhaps at 2 s. a Trap, becauſe they want them more; you ſhall go halves with me —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: And I'll get it done for you I'll warrant you — I have great Intereſt at Court, and I'll make it my buſineſs— Aſide. This was a happy encounter, and the moſt feaſible and rationable I ever undertook.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Sir, Mr. Turbulent is below, ſhall I ſend him up?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, ay — ſend him up Sirrah, is the Pottle of Butter'd Sack ready I ſpoke for?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Bring it up, and ſome Manchets to ſop in it — ſhew theſe Gentlemen another Room, you Rogue. Go Gentlemen, and diſcourſe your Affairs in the next Room, till I have occaſion for you.
I muſt firſt mollifie the Heart of my dear Uncle, before I can attempt my Buſineſs, and he will not drink with Strangers — Oh here comes the Sick Man —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Coughs, ugh—ugh—ugh— Nephew, you are a ſtrange man, to ſend for me out of Doors, when I have taken Phyſick, ugh—ugh—ugh— I fear I have gotten Cold already, that I have —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come Uncle, I have got ſome good butter'd Sherry; 'tis the beſt thing in the world after an Emettic. Boy, bring Wine and Manchets.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Your Docter Quibus thinks I'm mad, and gives me Pills of Hellebore to cure me— Let me tell you, he's a very ignorant abuſive Fellow, that he is.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: A mere Quack—but he has rare medecines. Come let him go— Uncle, here's a good draught to you—'twill breed good bloud—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis pure good and comfortable—'tis very hot Drinks and pauſes But Nephew, what is the earneſt buſineſs you ſent for me about?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'll tell you anon— Drink off your Cup firſt; 'tis good to keep out the cold—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well Nephew, I'll drink to you— (Drinks—) 'tis very extraordinary good—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'm glad you like it, Uncle—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: But Nephew, when ſhall I have the 500 l. you have promiſed me. If none thrive better by merchandizing than I did, there will be few Aldermen.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well Uncle, I ſhall pay you all very ſhortly with 30 per cent. Intereſt—You will ſee me in a very fair way to be Lord Mayor of London.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Would I could, Boy—I always had a kindneſs for thee— (Drinks, Furniſh fills his Cup—) 'Tis ſo hot it makes me ſweat.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (It begins to make him glow already—How he ſucks it down!—) 'Tis very good Uncle; you don't drink—Come a Health to my Aunt.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Piſh, an old woman without teeth—I'll drink no Healths; but if you'll begin a Remembrance to my Lady Medler, I'll pledge you—Oh that's a very loving Lady, and the beſt of a Court Lady I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Come away then, here's to her.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I'll think of her.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: He begins to be warm. (Fills again.) Come Uncle, t'other diſh, and I'll tell you my buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come then, under the Roſe, to your Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Well remember'd— Bravely done— I'll pledge you a Brimmer.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Truly methinks it has done me good—hem—hem—'tis a very excellent Creature—it cheers the heart— you can't think how light I am—But your buſineſs?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am always ſtudying your good Uncle — A Cat does not watch ſo diligently for a Mouſe, as I do for opportunities of ſerving you—Nay if you won't drink I won't tell you any more.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I do Nephew—come what is it?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I have met with a Gentleman of Cumberland one Mr. Peregrine Pricket, who has been in Holland theſe 7 years; his Father was a great Olivarian, and he is of the right ſtamp a Commonwealths man; his father died this laſt Chriſtmaſs, and has left him 400 l. a year, which he is now going to take poſſeſſion of.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And what's all this to me?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Nay, if you han't Patience to hear — why, he's a Batchelor, and wants a Wife; I having a great Intimacy with him, have recommended my Couſin Priſcilla to him, and let him know, I had 500 l. of hers in my Hand, put out for her Portion — and he promiſed me to meet me here by and by — for which end I ſent for you, that you might ſee him, and diſcourſe about it.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Four hundred pound a year ſay you —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, four hundred pound a year, and one alſo to your hearts wiſh — He has been bred up ſo long in Amſterdam, that he ſays, the very ſmell of Monarchical Air, makes him ſick, and is ranker in his Noſtrils than Lamp Oyl, or ſtinking Butter.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: That's a man cut out for me—but will he rail bravely againſt the Times? Hah! may a man ſpeak freely to him without fear—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis his whole delight; 'tis the true Liberty of a Butter-Box — He'll ſpeak againſt Governors and Magiſtrates, as if they were Scavengers or Chimney-ſweepers — and as reverently of Princes and Lords, as if they were Tapſters and Hoſtlers —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: A rare Fellow — I love him already — but you know Priſc. is a Quaker — how will he like that?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Twill pleaſe him the better, he is a Muggletonian; and as for manners, has as little as any Quaker of them all, and as for Thee and Thou, he ſays, it was the Language of Adam and Eve—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: A rare Fellow indeed — better and better (Drinks.) Well Dear, Dear, loving Nephew, I can't but hug thee for this news — This w • llcome Tidings, and the good Wine has chear'd my Heart— Come Nephew, have you forgot all your Old Songs —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No Uncle, I will ſing any that you like.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh ſing the Hymn of the High-way-man —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What — I keep my Horſe, I keep my Whore?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I, that— that—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (So now it begins to work — what pains am I fain to take, to open the cloſe-lock'd-heart of this covetous Uncle of mine) well • 'll ſing it Uncle.
sp.stage: Turbulent ſets himſelf in an antick Poſture, ſtaring with his eyes, and holding his hands like a Changeling, ſinging after him all the while — nodding his Head up and down.

l.hi: I keep my Horſe — I keep my Whore,
I take no Rents, yet am not poor —
I travel all the Land about,
And yet was born to never a foot
With Partridge plump, and Woodcock fine
I do at Midnight often dine;
And if my Whore be not in Caſe,
My Hoſteſs Daughter takes her Place.
The Maids ſit up, and watch their turns;
If I ſtay long the Tapſter mourns.
The Cook-maid has no mind to ſin,
Tho' tempted by the Chamberlain:
But when I knock, Oh how they buſtle,
The Hoſtler yawns, the Geldings juſtle;
If Maid but ſleep, Oh how they curſe her,
And all this comes of deliver your Purſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh that once again, dear Nephew — Sings, but when I knock, &c.—

div.stage: Furniſh knocks and whiſpers the Drawer.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Bid the Gentlemen in the next Room come in, I have wrought him up to the right Cue —now can I mould him like Wax.)
Oh Uncle, here's the Gentleman I ſpoke to you of.

div.p: Mr. Peregrine Pricket — your Servaut Sir — This is my Uncle Sir I ſpoke to you of.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Sir I ſhall be happy to be made known to you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I have heard of your worth Sir, by my good Nephew, here, will you ſit Sir, and do as we do? I was not very well, and my good Nephew has provided for me ſome butter'd Sack — Sir, here's to you.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Mr. Furniſh has promiſed to furniſh me with a Commodity that I want — a Wife Sir — and has told me of a Daughter of yours, Mrs. Priſcilla, I think he call'd her, a very Religious and Godly Virgin — 'Tis my deſire, Sir, to marry into a Religious Family— I am newly come to my Eſtate, and will ſettle 200 l. a year Joynture: As for her Portion, I know it already, I dare take Mr. Furniſhe's word for it.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I ſee Sir, we ſhan't be long a making up this Match; I like you, and your Eſtate, and you like me and the Portion; now if you and my Daughter like one another, the Buſineſs is done.

div.stage: Whilſt they are talking, Furniſh and Sneak go out.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: No queſtion but I ſhall like her, I have heard ſo much of her many Excellencies and good Qualities; the worſt that I know of her, is her Skill in Logic; I do not love to have my Wife have more Logic than I; ſhe'll ſay or do any thing, and prove it by Logic.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Indeed you ſay true — I have told her often of it, and that ſhe ſhould not love Reaſon ſo well — Indeed I muſt confeſs, Logic is her worſt fault — but when ſhe is married, you'll find other Buſineſs for her than poring in Logic Books.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I was a while at School at Leyden, and if I can remember any of my Old Leſſons, I'll Court her that way —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: that will win her Heart — but 'tis no matter, Mr. Pricket, I have the Spirit of Government, and ſteer the Helm of the Commonwealth in my own Family — ſhe ſhall have you — like or like not —and it ſhall be as I pleaſe—I am the Speaker in my Family.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But that will be too tyrannical to compell her — but if there be the major Voices of the Family, I think ſhe may then be lawfully compelled —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You ſay very well, and it ſhall go by your Voices — I ſee you are a true Commonwealths-man — But we live in ſad times—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Ay, Times of Aegyptian Darkneſs.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Whilſt Men eat, and drink, and riſe up to play —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Till their Eyes cannot look out with Fatneſs.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: They wallow in the Puddle of Filthineſs.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: And roll themſelves in the Sink of Sin — Oh, the Riotouſneſs and Wickedneſs of this Age —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: The Villanies, the Whoredoms, the Fornications, the Adulteries, the Pride, Folly, and Vain-glory of this Age.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: This wanton, luxurious, exorbitant, abominable, ſcurrilous, cheating, bribing, couſining, and treacherous Age—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: This libidinous, licentious, lacivious, lying, lazie, latitudinarian Age—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: (He has a moſt run me out of Breath—He is too well practic'd at this ſport) well Sir, in the mean time, here's to you—I'll ha your Danghter, and Joynter her bravely—

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Oh Sir. Mr. Furniſh is taken below with an Execution, and the Serjants are having him away to Priſon—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: What ill Chance is this — juſt as I am about the preferment of my Daughter—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Uncle if you don't help me at this pinch I am undone—I had got Money to have paid this, but only my promiſe to meet Mr. Pricket and you here made me neglect it—
'Tis but for 50 l. don't ſpoil your Daughter's Fortune, and play the Fool to deny it—He ſhall be bound with me to you for it—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You are a ſtrange man that you are—I proteſted and vow'd, I'de nere lend you any more, and yet you have ſuch fetches—I think I'm bewitch'd with you.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Speak ſoftly—don't ſpoil your Daughters Fortune for 50 l. he has 400 l. a Year, I know he'll be bound, but has no Money at preſent—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: If he'll be bound with you and Mr. Sneak; I'll do it for this once—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Thank you Uncle—Well Serjants, if you'll go into the next Room and call for a Bottle of Wine, I'le give you a Note to receive the Money, and pay you for your Civility—

sp.speaker: Serj.
sp.p: We will Sir—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (Afide to Hangby) If I had not made him drunk, he would have let me agon to Tiburn, before he would have parted with 50 l. and ſpoil'd his Daughter Priſcis Fortune to boot—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But where hadſt thou theſe counterfeit Serjants ſo readily—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Oh I had them ready at hand—I had lai'd my deſign—now ſecond me—

Well Uncle, I have perſwaded Mr. Pricket and Mr. Sneake to be bound with me to you in a 100 l. Bond for the payment of 50—I have a Blank Bond ready—I'll fil it up—and do you in the mean time draw a Note upon Mr. Scrible your Scrivener, that will ſerve—

div.stage: Draws out Bond and Pen and Ink—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well Nephew you are the ſtrangeſt man, I know not how to deny you any thing—but what time?—Nephew, ſet your day and be punctual.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I'll deſire it but for a Month, and you ſhall have 20 s. and a Collation when I pay it, for your kindneſs.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Well fill up the Bond—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Turbulent, Mr. Turbulent, I am ſorry at heart, and grieved in Spirit to ſee you within the walls of a vile and abominable Tavern—I am afraid it is as Dr. Quibus ſays, you are not in your right Senſes, to ſet your foot within this unſanctified and Anti-Chriſtian Houſe, this Image of Babel. Does not Anti-Chriſt hang out at the door for a Sign, the very Image of the Beaſt, with his Trible Crown, and the Buſh of the Babyloniſh Whore hanging before him: Oh Mr. Turbulent it is abominable, and you are become defiled—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What a miſchief is this—the Devil has outwitted me, and ſent this Furie before the Bond was ſeal'd—

sp.speaker: Mrs.
sp.p: Turbulent runs to the Table, and ſnatches up the Bond.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: What is this you are doing—are you entering indeed into more Bonds—Oh that wicked, curſed, abominable Nephew of yours, that will utterly undo you at laſt, and leave you not worth one groat—He has already drawn you into ſo many Bonds and Obligations, that you'll have nothing ere long, but muſt be fain to beg thorow the Grate at Ludgate—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Good Aunt be pacified—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I won't be pacified, and he ſhall not be bound in Bonds, and I will ſee what it is, and I will look on it my ſelf—

sp.speaker: Yur.
sp.p: You're an Aſs, and Fool, meddle with your own matters, and go about your buſineſs, who ſent for you hither—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: This is my buſineſs, and this my matters, and I will ſee what 'tis—

div.stage: Puts on her Spectacles, Mr. Turbulent ſtanding in the middle, and Mr. Furniſh and Sneak on each ſide with Hats off, Hangby at a diſtance as if amazed.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You're a Fool, tis Latin and you can't underſtand it.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: You're a Coxcomb, I underſtand it as well as your ſelf— but I'll tell you, 'tis the Language of the Beaſt, and one of the Confuſions of Babel; reads Noverint univerſity—

div.stage: Puts off her Spectacles when ſhe ſpeaks, then puts them on again every time.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Away you old doting Dunce, read the Condition let the Bond none.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I will not read the Condition, I will have no Conditions, and there ſhall be no Bonds; and if I can't read it I'll carry it to my brother Mopus of Grays Inn, and he ſhall read it— Reads Noverint univerſity; I thought what 'twas.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis not univerſity.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis univerſity—and the wicked, abominable univerſities, where the Youth are trained up in all the vile Languages of Babel.

div.stage: Falls into a Fit of Coughing; her Spectacles fall down.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: So her Eyes are gone, I hope—they are broke—would ſhe were choak'd—Good Aunt, drink a Glaſs of wine, 'twill ſtop your Coughing; you ſpeak too faſt.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I'll drink none of your unſanctified liquor of the Devil's brewing, that cauſes Drunkenneſs, Fornication, Whoredom, Adultery, Fightings, Brawlings, Cheatings, Trepannings, Cozenings, and all the villany and abomination that is committed in theſe lewd houſes of Sin, Iniquity, and Pollution— Coughs again— Oh get me a little water—

div.stage: Knock, Enter Boy. — haſt thou any water in the houſe?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Yes very good, from Anniſacleer, the beſt as ere you drank.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Fetch me ſome quickly—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: You Rogue, bring up a Bottle of White-wine and a Beer-glaſs. —quickly Sirrah, no water.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Mr. Turbulent, I fear you cannot well ſteer the Helm of Government in your own family; Mrs. Turbulent is very rough, ſhe ſeems not to be ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I will let her alone here, but when ſhe comes home I will reprove her in the heat of my zeal, and ſhe ſhall be ſatisfied.

div.stage: Enter Boy and Wine, fills, gives to Mrs. Turbulent. She is coughing ſtill.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Here Aunt, here is a Glaſs of water—but I ſhould think you hadbetter drink wine.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Not in this unhallowed place—I think this water is not very clear.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis very good, drink it up.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis very good water, and reliſhes well—where do you get this water?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: We have it come into the Cellar in Pipes.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: My Pipe-water is not half ſo good as this; Mr. Turbulent, I will have of the ſame water as this is, 'tis very pleaſant taſted water.
sp.stage: Mr. Turbulent begins to heave as if he would vomit.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Turbulent, thou art overcome with the creature; thou haſt committed vileneſs in the ſight of the people, and drunk beyond thy meaſure—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hold your prating, you will ſpoil your Daughters preferment— Hark, I tell you the buſineſs.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Here Aunt, ſtop the coughing— I hope 'twill mollifie the iraſcible quality.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh this filthy Cough — it interrupts me — give me the Water —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Would it would choak thee too for me — Is it not good Water? —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh 'tis very excellent Water — is it as Mr. Turbulent tells me? —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Yes—Yes— he has 400 l. a Year, and offers to Joynter my Couſin in 200 l. and you had like to ſpoil all —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Nay, if it be ſo, I ſhall reſt ſatisfied —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: (God a mercy Wine, ſhe would not hear before — I find it is of a mollifying Nature) give another Glaſs of Water to my Aunt; Doctor Quibus ſays it is very good againſt the Cough.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: And he is a very Learned Doctor, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Boy, Drawer — ſhew me another Room where there is a Bed, I muſt lie down a little —

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I will Sir —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Lead me Boy —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Bleſs me, my Uncle is ſtole out to take a Nap; if he grows ſober, he'll ne're ſign the Note I have drawn for the 50 l. — Come Hangby, let's follow him and get it done while he's in the Humor.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I do intend to make Mrs. Priſcilla my wedded Wife.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I underſtand as much — I was too paſſionate, and did not underſtand your worth, and that you were not one of the wicked of the Earth; but ſelected from this Generation of Vipers —

sp.speaker: Han.
sp.p: It was the Cauſe of Matrimony that drew me into this place, and engaged me into the Temples of the Ungodly —

sp.speaker: Mrs Tur.
sp.p: I am extreamly ſatisfied in your Behavior and Company — Where's Mr. Turbulent?

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: He's gone to lie down a little on the Bed in the next Room — Let us get him to ſign the Bond to my Uncle preſently —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Mr. Pricket, let us go in to Mr. Turbulent — I will ſend for my Daughter Priſc. for once into this place — thou haſt made the Houſe of Uncleanneſs pure by thy Preſence. Shew us the way, Nephew Furniſh —

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Will you tell Mr. Furniſh I am here, and deſire to ſpeak with him?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: preſently Sir.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I ſhall now ſee whether he accuſes my Chicken falſly — I am ſomething hard of Belief — yet I may judge of her by my own Frailty; all Fleſh is ſubject to back-ſliding.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: You ſee I am come Mr. Furniſh, I walk'd round the Walk and could not ſee my Chicken, I believe you ſcandalize her —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: That you ſhall know preſently — Boy, fetch me the Periwig Hat, and Coat I gave you to lay up.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: I ſhall. Sir.

div.p: You will find your error, Mr. Sly, that you ſhould not believe your ſelf a Cukold — Do you think your blew-apron'd Shopkeepers wives to be more chaſt than the Court Ladies?—I'll convince you.
div.stage: Enter Boy—they dreſs Sly with Wig, Coat, Hat;
div.p: Nay, you ſhall have a Sword too, elſe perhaps ſhe'll refuſe you—You ſhall have mine.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I think ſhe can't know me.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No, not if you alter a little the ſqueeking of your voice — You muſt ſpeak little — You'll find her willing without much courting — Come hither Mr. Sly, look yonder, — what think you of that Gentlewoman?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I proteſt and vow 'tis my Chicken, I know her by her amble; 'tis the right motion of her Buttocks — I'll be with her — preſently —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: So, you have the Note for the 50 l.

sp.speaker: Fur,
sp.p: Safe enough, Boy — and will have the money to morrow morning; but where's my Aunt?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: She is within, and grown the kindeſt loving Soul as ever you knew — I was fain to ſteal out to get a little breath — ſhe has ſent for her daughter Pris too.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Go in again, I have a little buſineſs with this Gentlewoman; I'll come to you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Well Mr. Furniſh, I have walk'd twice round and can't meet my Chicken — there's never ſuch a man as you deſcrib'd him to be.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No!—come hither Mrs. Sly, look yonder, what think you of that Gallant with a long tail trailing after him?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Ods heartlikins 'tis my Chicken, I know him by his Dogtrot and Spindle-ſhank'd Legs — 'tis he, I'll to him — Have I caught you indeed!

div.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, Mrs. Turbulent, Hangby.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come Nephew, why do you leave us? we can't be without your good company.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I was juſt a coming, having diſpatch'd an affair of conſequence — where's Mr. Sneak?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I have ſent him for my daughter Pris — Mr. Pricket ſhall ſee her, that he ſhall.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Daughter, I have brought a Gentleman to be acquainted with you —

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Nay — thou haſt ſent for me to be acquainted with him — thou makeſt not a true propoſition.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Goſſip, you had beſt tell me I lie.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I ſay it not — thou mayſt ſay it — But what ſeeketh this man?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Mrs. Priſcilla, I ſeek thee for my wedded wife, that is the end of my ſeeking. What ſayſt thou, doſt thou like me?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thy propoſition is not Hypothetical.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: But it is Hypothetical, and may be either Conditional, Copulative, or Disjunctive.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: He ſpeaks rationally — thou ſayſt well, what is thy name?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I am called Peregrine Pricket.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I like not thy name.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Are you chopping Logick indeed? — I'll make you like both his name and him too.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Pray Sir, be not in the poſtpredicament of oppoſition — ſhe miſtakes the genus of my name — But Mrs. Priſeilla, nomen is quaſi notamen, a certain Image by which the King is known, and is the vocabulum proprium whereby we name a thing; or vocabulum quodlibet, by which ſomething is underſtood. I am called Peregrine Pricket, that is a Travelling Buck.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thou haſt ſpoken demonſtratively, and I am reconciled to thy ſenſe. But in what Relation doſt thou ſtand?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: [This is a rare Wench, ſhe'll do in Logie.] I ſhall tell you my buſineſs in a Categorical propoſition.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Let it then conſiſt as it ought, of one Subject, one Predicate, and one Copula.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Shitten come ſhites, leave your Moods and the Figures of your Copula's y'had beſt, and go to the buſineſs: do you like Mr. Pricket for a Husband?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thy queſtion may be determined univerſally, ſingularly, or particularly.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You're an univerſal, ſingular, and particular crack-brain'd Baggage, I'll make you know me and leave diſputing.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I fear thou art diſguiſed, and haſt taken too much of the creature, and drank of the polluted Springs which flow in theſe Cellars of the wicked.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Sly and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Have I caught you indeed! — Oh you Harlot!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Have I found out your haunts you wicked whoremaſter Rogue?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Oh you cuuning Gipſie, this ſhan't ſerve your turn.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Oh you beaſtly Hypocrite! what make you in this diſguiſe, with theſe Babyloniſh Garments, and the Sword of Perdition by thy ſide hunting after the Harlots in the twilight?

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Oh you painted Jezabel, with the Devils Patches on thy Face, and the frizled Hair on thy Forehead, that ſtandeſt here at the Corners of the Walls, to draw Young Men to Lewdneſs — Oh thou Midianitiſh Woman!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Oh thou luſtful Zimri — Thou abominable Philiſtine!

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I thought thou had'ſt been looking to thy Shop.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: I thought thou had'ſt been hearing Mr. Windy —

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Yes, you thought me ſafe enough, you Strumpet —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Ay, you thought me faſt enough, you Villain.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Did I take pity of you for this, when you ran about to all the Meetings in Town, to get a Husband, and left off your vain Attire, and put your ſelf into the preciſe Cut and Form — but I ſee you were a rank Hypocrite — Oh you luſtful Woman — am I one to make a Cuckold of?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Away you pretended Zealot — let me tear out his Eyes —

div.stage: Falls on him, and pulls off his Wigg — they hold her.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I am amazed — Oh Mr. Rabſhecah Sly. — I am amuſed to ſee thee transformed into the Shape of the Unrighteous; it will be a Scandal to all the good People: The Weekly Pamphlets will revile thee — Oh Brother, thou art fallen —

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Why d'ye accuſe me, that art worſe thy ſelf, I ſee thou art drunken, and walloweſt in thy Iniquity — Was it for this Mr. Turbulent, you were in ſuch haſte to break up the Meeting, to come into this lewd place? —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hah, hah, hah, hay — How theſe Hypocrites begin to lay open themſelves! How often have they lick'd one another, as Bears do their Cubbs, into a ſhape of Sanctity; or as Horſes, nabbing one another, with the Delight of railing at the Wicked? And now —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: They turn their Inſides outward, and appear in their true ſhapes — a formal Saint without, a very Beaſt within —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Mr. Pricket, pray be not ſcandalized at theſe things — I perceive 'tis the Frailty of the Fleſh, and they are both fallen from their firſt Station.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I, ſo they are, they have found one another faulty, it is beſt to make up the Breach.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Phillipaſly, Thou art in the ſame Predicament with thy Huſband, you are both diſguiſed, therefore thou oughteſt not to exclaim, but let the matter be ſifted by Diviſion and Sub-diviſion, that ſo the Truth may be found out —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Prittle — prattle — let me alone — leave me, don't hold me; let me come at the Whore-maſter-rogue; I will give him a Mark: I will ſtrip him of his wicked Habiliments —

div.stage: Enter Conſtables, with man of the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Man.
sp.p: Come, take 'em away to Juſtice Right-or-wrong, away with 'em; do they come here to make a Diſturbance, and to bring a Scandal upon my Houſe? Away with 'em both Mr. Conſtable — the Juſtice will find out the matter —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hah, hah, hah — I think I am even with 'em

div.stage: Seiſe Sly, and Mrs. Sly — carry them forth.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: This is the place of Confuſion, I will retire — Mr. Pricket, I hope you will come to my Houſe; we ſhall there diſcourſe matters betters —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I ſhall not fail to viſit you —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Come Mr. Turbulent, let us depart in peace; I am ſorry for the falling away of Brother Sly — his Gifts were many —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I will go with you —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Mr. Sneak, pray do the kind Office for me, as to wait on my Aunt home — I have a little Buſineſs with Mr. Pricket —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Nephew, good Night — Mr. Pricket, I ſhall be glad to ſee you at my Houſe —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: I ſhall wait on you to morrow —

div.stage: Exeunt all but Furniſh and Hangby.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Ay, that you ſhall to night — you Rogue.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: This 50 l. was eaſily got, I was damnably afraid of it, when I ſaw the Dragoneſs my Aunt come in — Come in, I have another Shape to put thee in to night — Come away —

l.hi: Fools are a Prey to Knaves, ſmall Knaves to great,
Cullies to Gameſters; the whole World's a Cheat.

div.trailer: The End of the Third Act.

div.head: The Fourth Act.
The Scene Mr. Turbulent's Houſe.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: WEll Frank, ſince 'tis ſo decreed; and that the Law of thy own Will has paſs'd upon thee, I will be ſo much a Friend, as not to leave thee till I ſee the Execution of Matrimony executed.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And my Body fairly beſtow'd in the Arms of Lucia.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Let it be ſo then; I'll ſee thee fairly noos'd, and then buried, and ſo I'll leave thee — The Report you have given me of this Houſe, makes me afraid of Hobgoblins.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: They are all abroad, and my Angel Lucia left its Guardian only at this time.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I dread that Finical Fellow Cringe —

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee learn to laugh at the Follies of the World as I do; for me thinks, nothing can be more ridiculous, than to ſee a man angry with Apes and Monkies, for acting their Natures; I tell thee they are made on purpoſe to make wiſe men laugh.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I know not what Temper my Spleen is made on; but they rather turn my Stomach, than make me ſmile.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: You ſee, dear Lucy, I am diligent to obey your Commands.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You do but ſet me a Pattern of what I muſt do all my Life time after to morrow.

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: But what neceſſity is there, Madam, that both of you muſt be ſo heavily yoak'd? Can't you keep together in a fair Paſture; without a Glog about your Heels, or a Yoak about your Necks — 'Faith Madam, if you'd follow my Advice, you ſhould take one anothers Words.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I doubt, Mr. Friendly, you would hardly put out 1000 l. without ſome other Security than the bare word of your Truſtee; and though I dare truſt all my deareſt Concerns into the Hands of Mr. Fairlove, upon the Security of his Word; yet ſince it is cuſtomable for Form-ſake, we will enterchangeably enter into the Bonds of Matrimony.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I ſee you are reſolv'd, and that no Reaſons nor Perſuaſions can change you. This Cuſtom is a plaguy thing: There's no Remedy for Time out of mind; becauſe our Fathers and Mothers, and great, great Grand-fathers and Grand-mothers wore thoſe Bonds of Marriage, we muſt.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee Friendly, leave off, did not you promiſe me you would ſay no more?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: 'Tis hard to ſee you on a Precipice, and not warn you of it — I'll ſay no more, here's my Hand on't; but I'll go with you, as one Friend does with another, that is, going to the Gallows, with a great deal of Grief and Compaſſion, to ſee you fairly Halter'd.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Madam Lucia, your Uncle and Aunt are returned from the Tavern; but ſo chirping and merry, their Eyes twincle, their Tongu • s run, and their Faces ſhine, that you would ſcarce think them the ſame turbulent, noyſom Creatures they uſe to be.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This Furniſh has ſpoil'd my Deſign. But 'tis my Admiration by what Charm he could unite them ſo lovingly.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh you know not the Charms of Wine, as they can make the greateſt Friends fall out, ſo they can reconcile the ſtubborneſt Foes, Man and Wife.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I muſt ſet them again at Odds, or I ſhan't work my Intention — I know how to do it.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Prethee let us be gone, I would not ſee theſe Hobgoblins.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, Mr. Friendly, you ſhall bear Mr. Fairlove Company a while— Pollux, light them into that Parlor, a while, it ſhall not be long e're I wait on you again.

div.stage: Exeunt Pollux lighting in Fairlove and Friendly.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam Lucia, your humble Servant —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Mr. Grin Sneak, your Servant — what a foot ſtill, and in Old Cloaths? Do none of your Projects hit yet? Where ſtick they, Mr. Sneak? —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Well Madam, we ſhall be happy at laſt — I'm in a fair way —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: To Beggery.

But Mr. Sneak, I have met with a man, that has been this forty
eight years ſtudying a rare Project, and indeed, one that will be beneficial to all Curious Perſons; and eſpecially to Travellers; and he tells me, that now at laſt he has attained it; and that he ſhall have perfected his Deſign by that time the Patent can be got for it.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, what is this rare Invention you ſpeak of?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, the Invention is extraordinary, it is a pair of Wings to fly into the Moon.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Why, that is not poſſible.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How unreaſonable you are now, not to believe another, and yet impoſe as impoſſible things on the Faith of others? And to tell you very freely, Mr. Sneak, my thoughts are, 'twill be ſooner effected than moſt of thoſe things you dream of: For you cannot but know, that Dedalus and Icarus could fly half way to the Moon; and of ſeveral others, that could fly from high Towers, like Kites, or Eagles.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Indeed, it would be an admirable way of Travelling; I'll ſpeak to my Lady Medler about the Patent.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis good to ſpeak in time: It will be of extraordinary Benefit to you; and I hope, worth the Vertuoſo's while, labor and pains. He has ſtudied all the Mathematicks, and run thorow the Philoſophy of Atoms, of Weight and Gravity; weighed all ſorts of Air, and lain whole days on his Back, to obſerve the Motions of Kites, Swallows, Doves, Batts, and Butterflies, making Comments and Obſervations on their ſeveral Motions; and now at laſt Mr. Sneak, this Flying Man, having brought his Wings to perfection, intends to viſit the Moon ſhortly.

sp.speaker: Se.
sp.p: Let me adviſe him to get a Patent before he goes, and to communicate his Art to one, leaſt he ſhould miſcarry: For I look upon the Voyage far more dangerous than that of Columbus, when he went in urſuit of the other World.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: As to the laſt, I may perhaps get him to communicate it to you: For he is almoſt afraid to own it after all, leaſt he ſhould be knock'd on the Head, by the Coachmen, Watermen and Seamen: For 'twill ſpoil their Trade. Beſides, ſome have perſuaded the Huſband-men, that there will (if this Project goes forward) be ſuch Clouds of Flying People in the Air, that 'twill hinder the Sun from ripening their Corn: So that he is afraid he ſhall be kill'd by them for the Invention; and he muſt be upon the Wing, out of the reach of ſhot, or in the Moon to ſecure himſelf.

div.p: Oh here's your Friend my Lady Medler! I'll leave you to diſcourſe your Affairs —
div.stage: Sneak turns about. and pulling his Handkerchief out of his Pocket, drops a Paper, which Lucia takes up —

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p:
I have run all over the Town to look you out; I wonder what you do here, when you have ſo many grand Concerns on foot. I aſſure you, Mr. Sneak, if you will not be more quick and brisk
in the Buſineſs, I ſhall leave you, and all your Patents together; and then ſee what you will make of 'em.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: O Pray Madam, be not angry, I was engaged in a very grand Deſign, one of the beſt Projects I ever yet met with, very feaſible and extreamly beneficial, which I will communicate to your Ladyſhip.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: But Mr. Sneak, I have met with a Project this day, ſo extraordinary, and ſo exceeding beneficial, both to us, and to the whole Kingdom, that I hug my ſelf, to have been ſo happy as to hear the firſt Propoſition of it, from the Vertuoſo himſelf — I will take you in for a Share, Mr. Sneak, we will make one another happy —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam, you honour your Servant, pray what is it?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Why, there is a perſon come to Town, that was with me this day, that propoſes to build a Fleet of Sheeps all of Portland Stone, to ſave the Woods which begin to grow thin, and Timber ſcarce; and he will undertake to build them ſo thick, that no Bullet ſhall pierce them. Then we ſhall have Caſtles indeed floating on the Seas, as a modern Poet ſays.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Sure that is not feaſible, which way can he do it; he muſt ſheath them all with Cork ſure?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Nay, which way he does it, is a Secret; but he has brought it to Demonſtration already by a little one, the very Yards and Maſts are all of Stone too.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: But the Tackle and Sales are not made of Stone too, I hope.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: No — but they are not of Hemp nor Canvaſs.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Becauſe we may not be beholden to Forreign Nations, and to promote the Growth of our own Nation, all the Sales are made of Tinn, and the Shrouds, Tackle and Cables of twiſted Wires. What need we then care for Denmark or Norway?

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: 'Tis admirable; and if he can but convince me by Demonſtration, I ſhall look upon it as the moſt happy thing I ever light on. I beſeech you, Madam, promote it for the Good of the Nation.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I intend it, I aſſure you, I am this Night to give the Gentleman a meeting about it: You ſhall go with me in my Coach; and as we go, you ſhall communicate to me the happy Project you have met with this day. Come in with me, I will but ſpeak two words to Mr. Turbulent, and we'll go.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What have I got here — ſomething that dropt from Mr. Sneak; I muſt ſee what 'tis —
sp.stage: An Account of my Eſtate in Poſſe
sp.p: Very good! I ſhall ſee how rich this Gentleman is in Poſſe, when I'm ſure he has not any thing in Eſſe.
Imprimis, My Share in the Flax-Buſineſs, at 20 l. per Week 1000 l. a Year.

Item, My Concerns in my Black Box, being ſeveral Bonds, Mortgages,
Defeaſances, and Statute-Staples, worth 20000 l.
Item, For procuring the Patent for the Conſulſhip of Marſelles 200 l.
Item, When the Match is made between my Lord Muchland's Son, and Juſtice Gripewell's Grand-child — 1000 l.

div.p: 'Tis too long to read — Oh, here he is come to look his Paper— I'll ſee the Summa totalis — 200000 l. a very fair Eſtate — This man is fit for Bedlam: I muſt do him the kindneſs to ſend him thither with my Uncle, that he may be cur'd.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Oh Madam, I think that's the Paper I was looking for; I would not have loſt it for any thing.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why, Mr. Sneak, it does but let us know how rich you are —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: No Madam, how rich I am like to be — And if Fortune does not oppoſe too much, I am like to be competuntly happy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Here Sir — [Gives him his Paper] I think you are happy already, that can content your ſelf with an Eſtate in Paſſe, whilſt there is nothing but Air in your Pockets. I doubt, your Old Bills and Lands, and all your new Projects will come to little —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I cannot ſtay now Madam, to convince you, my Lady Medler ſtays for me; or elſe I'd let you underſtand, that I do not take falſe meaſures — Madam, your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Thou art the confidenteſt Projecting Fool, that ever I met with, whom neither being baffled, laughed at, gull'd and cheated, can convince; whom the Counter, Kings-Bench, Want, nor Miſery, can convert, or make feaſible. There is but one Refuge left for thee, and that is Bedlam.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Mr. Furniſh is come fitted to all purpoſes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That's well, where's my Uncle?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Lain down to take a Nap — he has been a ſleep a good while —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Go you to my Couſin Furniſh, tell him, I'll be with him preſently. I'll ſpeak but two words to Mr. Fairlove, and I'll follow you.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Turbulent, with his Cap on.
div.p: So, I have ſettled my Head with this Nap; my Stomach begins to crave Victuals — I am grieved, that Mr. Sly, and his Wife ſhould give ſuch Occaſion of Scandal to the Wicked —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Did you call Sir? —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Yes Sirrah. Where's the Miſtreſs?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Gone to her Singing-Meeting, in Sun-dial-Alley.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Where is Priſcilla?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Gone to viſit one of her Brothers hard by; ſhe ſaid ſhe would not ſtay —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p:
Set me the Candle, and the Box of Books: I will read till
they return —
sp.stage: Candle, and black Box ſet by him, and Table.
sp.p: So Paul, get me ready half a dozen Turky Eggs for my Supper —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I ſhall Sir — I doubt you won't ſtay to eat 'em

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: O Uncle, Uncle. we are undone for ever: For God's ſake hide your ſelf ſtreight, or you'll be taken.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: (Starts up, and looks frighted) What's the matter Lucia — why do you fright me thus?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Fright you? why, the Parlor below is full of Souldiers, they are come to have you away to Priſon —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh ſad Times — What Times do we live in, that a man cannot be quiet in his Houſe, which is his Caſtle, what have I done?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, no expoſtulating now — you have been letting your Tongue run at London, and talk'd Treaſon: They ſay too, one Mr. Pricket is a meer Informer, and will witneſs againſt you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: O wicked and abominable Age — O baſe Impoſtor, Vile Varlet, Hypocrite, Wretch — Lucy, what ſhall I do? — I ſhall be undone if I'm taken —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh Sir, hide, hide your ſelf, here are I know not how many Souldiers, Red-Coats, and an Officer to ſearch for you: they are juſt coming up Stairs.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now is your time to make uſe of your Armor. Come, come away, put your ſelf into the Poſture, and avoid being taken.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come good Lucy, help me, I tremble, I know not what to do — Paul, Go down and divert them a little: Say I an abroad, any thing —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I ſhall do my endeavor —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, let us in quickly — I hear 'em coming. This comes of talking againſt the Times, with thoſe you know not —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh I hear them coming — Oh, what ſhall I do? —

div.stage: Enter Furniſh, Hangby, and others, with Red Coats, like Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Where is this Traytor — Where is this Mr. Turbulent, that is troubling every Body; and ſtill railing againſt the Times? —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: As good Drinking, Whoreing, Cheating Times, as any ever were ſince the Creation —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: So, he is gone to hide — you have put him into a monſtrous Fright — I find he would be no good Martyr for the Cauſe —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Theſe troubleſome talking men are uſually great Cowards.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: what have I got here, a Box of Writings?
I hope I have light on the Judgment I confeſs'd to him for 500 l. If it be, I am very lucky — (opens the Box) Pſhaw — nothing but a Company of paltry Books —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: They are my Maſters choiceſt Library, I'll aſſure you, and things of great Value and Eſteem with him —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Hang 'em Pamphlets—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Let's ſee 'em, a man may as well be known by the Books he converſes with, as by the Company he keeps —

q.p: Ariſe Evans, and the Maid of Kent's Propheſies.
Theaura John, and motive Motions, Viſions.
Prin againſt Plays, Cards and Dice.
The Holy Lives of Knipper Dolling, and John of Leyden.

p.hi: Here be more — the ſecond part to the ſame Tune.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Moſt choice things — No Wonder that he is mad when he ſtudies theſe —

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: And rail againſt the Times — meddle with Government.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Perverting the Fooliſh, provoking the Froward, and ſpitting forth his Gall and Venom which he ſucks from theſe Weeds.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Which feeds the fooliſh Hopes, and idle Fancies of ſuch Lunatick Brains.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Who call every vain Dream a Prophecy, and every idle Chymical Fancy a Viſion — Good Pollux, fling theſe Books into the Fire; 'twell be a very great Inducement towards my Uncle's Cure —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well, my Uncle is hid; but you may find him in the Preſs, in a little Room within his Chamber, he is ſufficiently frighted — He ſays Mr. Pricket is a wicked man — You know the way Couſin Furniſh— Fright him as much as you will; but do not touch him —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: No—no— we won't hurt him —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Pollux. Go you to Mr. Fairlove and Mr. Friendly, and bring them to us — Fairlove ſhall ſee my Uncle Turbulent in Diſguiſe—

div.stage: A Preſs diſcovered. Enter Furniſh, Hangby, Souldiers, after them Lucia.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Where is this Traytor? — He muſt be about the Houſe — I'llleave no Corner unſearch'd —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You ſee he is not here — won't you be ſatisfied?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Come let's ſee what's in this Preſs — open it, where's the Key —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There's nothing there I'll aſſure you but a Statue.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Open it, or wee'll break it open — I muſt and will ſee what's in it—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: There may be Arms hid there for ought we know —

div.stage: Lucia opens the Preſs, Mr. Turbulent diſcovered in it, ſtanding bolt upright, armed Cap a pe, all of Brown Paper, with a Truncheon in his Hand; he ſtands without any Motion, imitating a Statue.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Look you there, to ſatisfie you, here is nothing, but a meer Statue of my Uncle's, that was ſent him for a Preſent.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: What have we here, — a Jack in a Box?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Bevis of Southampton.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: 'Tis John of Gaunt —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No Sir, 'tis John of Leyden, as he march'd before his Anabaptiſtical Army.

div.stage: Enter Pollux, Mr. Fairlove, and Friendly.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Look you Sir, there ſtands my Maſter Mr. Turbulent in his Poſture, in a Suit of Arms of his own making: Does not he look much like a General?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Prethee tell me Friendly, can'ſt forbear laughing now?

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I confeſs this is extraordinary, and I will as ſoon give two pence to ſee this, as e're a Monſter, or ſtrange Sight in Bartholomew Fair — Is it poſſible this Fellow ſhould have ſo little Sence in him.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: How ſtill he ſtands! he is faſt frozen with Fear.

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: This is a meer Teraphim, and this Mr. Turbulent a meer Heathen Idolater — and here he keeps his great Idol in Secret — I ſhall inform of this, and have him burnt for a Pagan.—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: No, no, you are miſtaken, 'tis the direct Image of Oliver; he cannot be content to adore him in his Heart; but he ſets up his Image in his Preſs, and in his Chamber.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed Sir you are miſtaken, he never lov'd Oliver in his life, nor any Governor, nor Government — you do him a great deal of wrong: He was then the ſame Mr. Turbulent that he is now —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: I know he is a very turbulent, troubleſome fellow; but I did not think, that he, who was ſtill railing againſt Images and Idolatry, ſhould have them thus privately lock'd up in Preſſes, like thoſe in Weſtminſter Abby; but let it be whoſe Image it will, I'll ſhoot it.

div.stage: Preſents a Piſtol, the Image ſhakes, and lets fall the Truncheon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What do you mean Sir? Oh forbear Sir, 'tis a meer Image, a very harmleſs Statue, Sir, what, ſhoot a Statue? —Oh good Sir, by no means—

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: Look, look, the Statue ſhakes, and has let fall his Truncheon— 'tis a piece of Witchcraft —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis nothing but the ſhaking of the Preſs, that does not ſtand faſt—

She ſhuts the Preſs (Aſide to Mr. Turbulent) You bad like to have ſpoil'd all— ſtand ſtill— You ſee Gentlemen, Mr. Turbulent is not in the Houſe — Pray Gentlemen, now are ſatiſfied, leave us to our ſelves —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: We ſhall meet with him ſome time or other, and he ſhall pay dearly for all his Treaſonable Speeches, and for his Idol of John of Leyden too —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Come, you have frighted him ſufficiently—I am afraid he'll ſpoil his Armor behind —

sp.speaker: Fur.
sp.p: This has done me as much good as the 50 l. I have got of him to day — Come Hangby—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Fairlove, If you will walk down, I will wait on you inſtantly. Pollux and I muſt uncaſe my Uncle firſt, and deliver him out of the Fright we have put him in —

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: He owes you much for his Deliverance.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: She has made him Mr. Peacable inſtead of Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Oh, he never talks in Armor— [Exeunt Fairlove Friendly. Lucia opens the Preſs, and Mr. Turbulent putting up the Viſor of his Helmet, comes forth upon the Stage.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I Proteſt, your Fear had like t'have ſpoil'd all —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: (Shaking) Are they gone? Are you ſure they are gone?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes Sir, they are gone, and I have ſhut the Doors after them —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh, theſe are abominable Times, Oh, wicked and accurſed Age— Oh, that I ſhould live in ſuch Times, that a man muſt be afraid to ſpeak. Wicked Varlets, they'll go and inform I am an Heathen Idolater: What if they ſhould come again? How ſhould I eſcape? O the ſight of the Piſtol has put me into ſuch a Fright — See Neece, is not my Armor ſpoiled behind? I have been ſomething leaky—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: No, no, all's well — 'Tis Proof enough againſt ſuch Shot.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Shall I get your Supper ready Sir?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh theſe Rogues have frighted away my Stomach. The ſight of the Devil is not ſo terrible to me as thoſe Red Cloaths, with the Infernal Weapons of Muskets and Piſtols — But Neece, what ſhall I do if they ſhould come again? — I am afraid they will be here again to morrow — Oh! I dread a Priſon, and to be confined within Walls—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There is no better way for you, than to feign your ſelf mad Pollux, and I will keep your Council, and then you may ſay any thing, which will be an eaſe to your Spirit; and you may do what you will, they will then only pity you, and take all to be an effect of your Madneſs; and that which you ſaid likewiſe to Mr. Pricket — Madneſs you know excuſes many things.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p:
Mad ſay you? — I need not counterfeit that, I am almoſt
mad already, to ſee the Wickedneſs and Profaneneſs of the Age, the Vileneſs and Lewdneſs of the Times, the Filthineſs and Debauchery of this City, and the Ungodlineſs and Irreligion of the whole Nation — I ſay, I can be very eaſily mad; and I will be ſo to ſave my ſelf, and to avoid being taken in the Snare of the Wicked Red-coats—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You had beſt make Tryal Sir, how you can deceive my Old Miſtreſs and my Young Miſtreſs — if you can deceive them handſomly, then you may be confident you may deceive any body elſe—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Oh Sir, here is Doctor Quibus, practice firſt upon him — now try what you can do —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I'll leave you here to keep them aſunder; I muſt go to Mr. Fairlove

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Vat de Debil is dis? Mr. Turbulent in Armor? I come to ſee my Patient: Is dis he in dis Caſe? morblew— Vat art dow?— ſpeak—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I am Mars the God of War— I am Mars, I tell thee; and I will ſlay thee Pigmy.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: I am afraid Sir, my Maſter is a little beſides himſelf— he does not uſe to talk thus.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Ay, de Color is got into de Brain, and has turn'd de Brain vith de hot Fumes— He take de Phyſic in the Morn, he take de Caudle at de Noon, he go to de Meeeing in de Afternoon, and to de Tabern at de Night; all dis is enough to make de vel man man ſtark mad— He muſt have de Ellebore, de ſtrong Purge of de Ellebore, and de ſpare Diet, and be kept dark, dat he may be cured.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Thou art an Aſs Doctor, and underſtandeſt not any thing— Mars never eat Hellebore— You are no Son of Apollo; you are not Aeſculapius, I know him by his Beard— Thou art an Elf, born in Fairy Land, and haſt ſailed hither in an Egg-ſhell, to poyſon the Nation with Rats-bain and Dogs Turds: But I tell thee: I am Mars, and I will ſlay thee.

div.stage: Lays hold on his Sword, Pollux ſtops him,

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: De debil go vit dee—I will ſtay no longer— de vine is in his Brain— Go, go to de Sleep, and ſettle de Brain; or elſe to de Bedlam, dat is de fitteſt place for dee—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: So, did I not do well? —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes Sir admirably — admirably well— 'tis natural to you—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come, help me off with my Arms— Let us go in— and go, and get my Eggs ready— I am almoſt faint with Faſting.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But you muſt remember to be mad again when you ſee my Miſtreſs—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, let me alone.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Will. Friendly (like the Philoſopher that never laugh'd till he ſaw an Aſs eating Thiſtles, nabbing and pricking his Lips) could not chuſe but ſmile a little, when he ſaw your Uncle in his poſture.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You would hardly have believ'd this, had not your eyes been Witneſſes— I aſſure you this Suit of Armor was an Invention of his own Brain, as well as the Work of his own hands.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I confeſs, 'twas ſomething ſurprizing, and might prove Diverſion enough for thoſe that love to make themſelves ſport with the folly of others — but I pity him—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Ne'r pity him, 'tis his Nature; and you may as well pity a Swine for grunting, or a Dog for barking— you were no ſooner gone, and that we had releas'd him from his Fear; but he return'd to his old wont of railing againſt the Times.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: 'Tis impoſſible to convert him from that

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have but one way to do it—and I'll make a Tryal of it— Well, I'll diſmiſs you till to morrow—and then—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I will releaſe you from your Slavery.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: And with a Habeas Corpus remove her from one Priſon to another.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: That is as it may happen.

div.stage: Enter Cringe, Singing Fa la la la.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Away Fairlove— here is the fooliſh City Poet: I had rather meet a Ghoſt, than this troubleſome Fop— you ſhall have enough of your Miſtreſs to morrow—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mrs. Lucia, are you ſtill in the ſame mind you were in laſt time I ſaw you, hey?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes indeed am I Sir; and therefore let me not hear one word more either of Love or Verſes: For I hate them both, eſpecially from you.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Now did you think I would go hang or drown my ſelf, hey? — Fa, la, la, la, fa, la, la, la — Now are you deceiv'd: I won't ſo much as write an Elegy on our parting, hey? —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I care not what you do with your ſelf ſo you trouble not me.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: You ſhall ſee, I know what belongs to the fathomable Love of our Times hey? — Fa la la la — I'll love you no longer than you love Mr. Fa la la la — Pſhaw, 'twas only my Diverſion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I'm glad Mr. Cringe, you and I ſo well agree at parting — But are you provided of another Love? That's faſhionable too: You ought to have another Miſs or two—what ſays my Couſin Priſcilla?

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: She is not ſuch a Fool as you are; ſhe knows when ſhe is well profer'd: and look you—hey, to vex you hey— ſee I have [pulling out Parchment] ſcratch'd your Name out of the Licence, and put in Mrs. Priſcilla's: Do you ſee that, hey? — Fal la la, Fal la la la—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is a pleaſant Lover— Oh my Aunt—

div.p: Oh Aunt, here has befell us a moſt ſad Diſaſter ſince your went.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p:
