Here have been Soulders to ſearch for my Uncle, which made
him fly into his Brown Paper Arms, his laſt Refuge— But what with the Fear they put him in, the Wine he has drunk at the Tavern, and his chollerick melancholly Diſtemper, as Doctor Quibus calls it, he is quite beſides himſelf, and out of his Wits — The Houſe can hardly hold him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: O the ſad and deplorable Times that we live in, there have not been ſuch lewd, wicked Times ſince Adam — They talk of the Iron Age; I tell you this is a Flinty Age, or a meer ſtony, rocky, adamantive Age, that they cannot let a poor man be in quiet in his own houſe —O ſad—ſad—ſad Times— Oh Neece, theſe are abominable Times, and we are governed by the Nebuchadnezzars and Balſhazzars of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Now have I put her into a Fit of Railing: But Aunt, Doctor Quibus has been to ſee him, and he is ſo raging mad, that he had like to have beat the Doctor; he ſays, he's abſolutely diſtracted as any in Bedlam, and adviſes you, by all means, to put him in there to be cured—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I can't believe it— 'tis but a Fit— he'll be well again— Oh theſe Times—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: What agen?—Good Aunt let the Time, alone, and conſider what you have to do—Look—
Here is my Couſin Priſcilla— take her Advice.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: What is the Subject of your Diſcourſe, is it proper or common?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: The Subject is very proper: your Father is mad they ſay; and the Queſtion is, what ſhall we do with him? He is raging, and he will be too hot for the Houſe, and too troubleſome to us all.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Canſt thou prove it?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes, without a Syllogiſm—if you go to him, he will demonſtrate it—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: He is then in an evil predicament— for if he hath loſt his Reaſon, plainly he is a Brute.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: And therefore I would have your Mother provide for him a little Chamber in the Hoſpital over the way, till his Reaſon and his Knowledge return again to him: and where proper Phyſick, and fit Dyet may be adminiſtred to him—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: 'Tis true, his Reaſon may be actually loſt for a time; but it may be ſtill in Potentia, and may be recovered.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Why, what's the matter with Mr. Turbulent hey? He is mad ſure, hey? — I went to him about ſome earneſt buſineſs, and he flew at me like a Dragon: If it had not been for honeſt Paul, he would have murthered me, hey — what ails he? hey— how came he ſo? hey—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He's troubled with Melancholly Mr. Cringe, he is in a cholerick melancholly Fit—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: A cholerick fit indeed hey— I don't love to ſee ſuch cholerick Fits hey—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You are troubled with Melancholly too Mr. Cringe.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Who I? hah, hah, hey— who I? Fa la la la la—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Yes you Mr. Cringe, for all your fa la la la— You are troubled with the laughing Melancholly, the rhiming, verſifying Melancholy, the ſinging, light airy fa la Melancholly — Indeed you are far gone, and have need of Cure, Mr. Cringe, I adviſe for the beſt.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Miſtreſs Priſcilla, ſhe ſays, this out of mere ſpite, becauſe I have left her— Look here, I have put you into the Licence, and I'll marry you to morrow, hey—what ſay you hey? Here's my Hand hey—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I ſay, that this Propoſition may be in the Mode Puerpera, that is the poſſible Mode; or it may be Edentuli, the neceſſary Mode—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: And I'll go ſtudy an Epithalamium againſt to morrow, hey— Fa la la la la la.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I adviſe you Couſin to lay by your Modes and your Figures, and take Mr. Cringe while he is in in the Mood: you'll never get ſuch a Husband— Come. I'll ſee it done to morrow my ſelf —

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: If Mr. Turbulent be mad, he is under Tribulation: He is chaſtized for going to the profane Houſe called a Tavern.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: You muſt now place your ſelf Aunt, at the Helm of Government in your Family, and compell my Uncle, for his own good, to enter into Bedlam, and to be under Confinement, and ſubject to Government, which he always abhorr'd— O here is another of the Melanchollicks,
And the fitteſt perſon in the World to bear my Uncle Company— 'Tis pity they ſhould be parted, this is the Eye, and my Uncle the Tongue of Sedition—

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Where is Brother Turbulent? — I am returned from Brother Sly and Siſter Sly, who are put into Tribulation, and are entred into the Priſon called the Round-houſe, ſent thither by the Earthly Juſtice, Right-or-wrong— I come to condole with Brother Turbulent about this matter.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Alas Brother Abednego, Mr. Turbulent has loſt his Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Then he is purified— he ought not to have any thing to do with Reaſon— It is the Idol of the World, and the very Babel of the Sons of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Do'ſt thou ſpeak againſt Reaſon and Logic? I doubt thou art ignorant, and canſt not diſtinguiſh.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Logic is the very Language of Babel, and uſed by the carnal, and the profane men of the Earth.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So this is good, they are going together by the Ears about Logic and Reaſon, which they neither underſtand any more than a Gooſe or a Sea-gull.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt evilly of the beſt thing in the World: It is Reaſon only that diſtinguiſhes us from Beaſts.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p:
I fay Reaſon is the Filth and Scum of the Carnal Brain: It is the Sut and Fume of Hell: it ought to be baniſh'd, and not made
uſe of: it is the Froth of a corrupted mind: it is the Carnal Weapon of the wicked, learned men — And I ſay again, we ought to live above Reaſon, beyond Reaſon, and to Act againſt Reaſon, and contrary to Reaſon, and to pull down Reaſon, and to overthrow, overthrow, overthrow— the Idol Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Wilt thou give me leave to reply?

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Thou canſt not, ſhalt not reply, nor take the part of Reaſon— 'Tis that which cauſes the Rulers of the Earth to impoſe Laws on us: 'tis that which cauſes the outward Worſhip, and the congregating in Stone Churches: 'tis that which cauſes the Orders and the Ceremonies, the Inſtitutions, and the Schools, and the Univerſities, and the Study, and the Books and ſubtle Queſtions and Anſwers among the men of the World—'Tis the very Root of all Evil, and it muſt be confounded; and if Brother Turbulent has loſt his Reaſon, he is become perfect.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I muſt tell thee Friend, thou lyeſt, Reaſon ought not to be loſt, nor to be caſt down, nor confounded.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I ſay it is loſt, and ſhall be caſt down, and ſhall be confounded.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I ſay it ſhall not, and thou art a Beaſt without thy Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I ſay it ſhall, and thou art a very Beaſt with thy Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This is pleaſant— two irrational Animals, to fall out about what neither of them have— but here comes one will end their Diſpute—

div.stage: Entet Mr. Turbulent in his Night Gown and Cap, ſtaring like a mad man, his Hands bound behind him, and led in by Pollux.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Here they are, Mr. Suckthnmb with 'em, now ſee if you can deceive 'em, and the Viſioneer too— you may then deceive any body— Now Maſter, act your part bravely—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: I'll warrant you, let me alone to counterfeit—

sp.speaker: Suckthumb.
sp.p: Brother Turbulent, I have now the Interpretation of the Viſion, I had at our Meeting. The Eagle on the top of the Tree, was Brother Sly, the Tree was the Round-houſe where he is put; and the Dragon was that Dragon-like Juſtice Right-or-wrong, who hath devoured him—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: What ſayeſt thou? Didſt thou name the Dragon? hah— art thou Bell? hah—

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Do'ſt thou ſee a Viſion?

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Yes I ſee thee, the Gyant Gogmagog, that devoureſt the People— but I will encounter thee, and caſt thee to the Earth.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Peace, he propheſieth—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur. Tim.
sp.p: I am ſorry to ſee thee diſtracted. Do'ſt thou know me thy own Wife? — I am afraid to go near him, he ſtares ſo—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: You need not fear him: See I have bound his Hands — he can't hurt you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Why do'ſt not ſpeak to me Tim.? — They were vile Varlets, to afright the out of thy Sences—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Avaunt, thou art a Succubus, a Shee Devil; and from thy Womb proceeds the Spawn of Antichriſt: Thou art the Whore of Babylon, and I will overthrow thee—

div.stage: Runs towards her, Pol. holds him.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Oh vile and abominable man. Ay, ay, I ſee he is mad now, to abuſe his own dear Wife.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Peace, Peace, he ſpeaketh wonderful things, and high Myſteries He is in a Rapture, Siſter Turbulent, he meaneth not thy carnal Womb, he meaneth Spiritually — Hearken, I pray, with Attention — Theſe are Myſteries— and Raptures —

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: May I put thee a plain Propoſition?—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Thou art a She Crocodile, and feedeſt upon Croaking Frogs— nothing but dark Fumes paſſeth from thy Throat, and thy words are as the ſounding of empty Tubbs — I will tear up thy Idols, and caſt them into the Fire, and burn thy Molock Logick-Books as a Sacrifice.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Nay plainly, I ſee he is now diſtracted, he hath quite loſt his Reaſon.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I ſay he ſpeaketh great things, and they ought to be written in Braſs, with a Pen of Steel — They are high Propheſies, and the Interpretation may be given— Call not thy Father mad— He is become perfect, and has laid aſide his Reaſon, the Enſign of his Carnallity.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Oh the roaring of the Lions, and the howling of the Wolves, the Neighing of Horſes, and the beating of Drums, heark the noiſe of the Canons, and the daſhing of Rocks together — Heark again, the bellowing of Bulls, and the braying of Aſſes; there is a Battel between the Beaſts of the Earth, and the Fowls of the Air.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Theſe are wonderful things— Oh he ſeeth ſtrange Sights!

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Tim. Tim. thou art mad—I will ſeek a Cure for thee.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt have ſome Phyſick, that thou mayeſt regain thy reaſon, which thou mayeſt yet have in Potentia.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: He counterfeits bravely—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Hah hah hah! Come, you are all my Friends. I did but counterfeit, to ſee if I could deceive you— I muſt do this when the Souldiers come, that they may think I'm mad— Did not I do it bravely?—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Have a care Aunt— this is but a light Interval, as moſt mad people have— Come not near him, he is ſpiteful—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: No Tim. you do not uſe to counterfeit— I'm ſure you would not abuſe your own Wife, if you had not been mad.

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Doſt thou own thy ſelf a Counterfeit and a Deceiver? Nay, then we ought to ſhun thee. If thou art mad, we ought to run from thee, that thou mayeſt not hurt us: If thou art not mad, thou art then a Counterfeit and a Deceiver, and we ought not to keep thee Company. There is a Dilemma for thee — thou haſt brought thy ſelf plainly into this Dilemma.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Here Wife, untie my Hands that I may beat that Baggage: I'll teach her better Manners, you Quaking, Impudent Jilflirt—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I ſee Tim. you are falling again into a Fit, I ſee by the Roll of your Eyes—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: O you vile woman, won't you believe me? —

div.stage: Offers to run at her, with-held by Pollux.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Thou art returning into thy Rapture—

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: Rapture? You Fool, you Idiot, I tell thee I did but counterfeit—Unlooſe me—theſe wicked Women will take the Helm of Government out of my hand elſe—

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Brother, I am ſorry thou ſhould'ſt ſay, thou didſt counterfeit, that is the greateſt Sign I have yet ſeen of thy madneſs — be reconciled to thy ſelf, and own thy Raptures.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: I have made a fair hand on't, and counterfeited ſo well they won't believe me: I ſay, Brother unlooſe-theſe Bands —

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I dare not, if they were impoſed on thee by the Legal Authority of thy Wife, or her Lawful Miniſters: Let them be looſed by the ſame Authority, I ſhall not meddle with them; but I can ſuffer with thee, and will not leave thee in thy Affliction.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: A company of Rogues, Whores, Varlets, I'll teach you all to abuſe me thus.

div.stage: Offers in great rage to fall on them, is held by Pollux and Lucy.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Away Aunt— he's in another raging Fit, quickly, quickly away, come away—

div.stage: Mrs. Turbulent and Priſ. run out.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Nay, I ſee he is mad indeed now—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: He hath loſt his Reaſon—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Come Neece, undo my Hands—I have counterfeited ſo long, they won't believe me now—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: 'Tis true indeed Uncle; you do it very naturally, now you counterfeit your ſelf ſober— but you are mad ſtill— (Whiſpers) Uncle, ſhall I have my Portion, and marry Mr. Fairlove?

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: O I could tear you to pieces, you vile Wretch, you abominable Baggage— I'll eat thee up—that I will. Do you mock me, and ſport your ſelf with me? —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I thought that would put him into a Rage again. So Uncle, you are fallen into another Fit.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I will not leave him, I will ſtay with him till his Zeal is abated.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Sirrah Pollux, undo my Hands that I may beat them all into their right Sences.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Well Uncle, I'll leave you, and conſult with my Aunt about your Cure— Be ſure you keep him faſt Pol.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Ne'r fear—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Uncle, you had beſt go ſleep, and ſettle your Brain, 'tis late—

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Come Sir, ſhe adviſes well: will you ſee if you can reſt? The Chollerick Fumes trouble your Brain.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Sirrah leave prateing— I'll jeſt no longer: untie my hands I ſay— I'll make 'em know me. Do they rebell againſt their Head?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Indeed Sir, I dare not, Do you think I am wiſer than my Old Mrs. and my young Mrs. and Mrs. Lucy— I ſhould be madder than you, if I ſhould untie your hands — They have order'd to the contrary.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: They—they—they— they order?— this is fine; Oh I will be reveng'd on them for this.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Poſſeſs your ſelf with patience— I will aſſiſt thee, and we will ſpeak to Siſter Kate once more—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Speak-patience ſay you? I'll after them, and tear them to pieces with my Teeth, vile, abominable, wretched, wicked, ſtinking, filthy Women—

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: He is again fallen into a Rapture— I will follow and ſee the-end of theſe things.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: So — There will be ſomething to do among 'em.

l.hi: Theſe ſort of men, your Holy Melanchollicks,
Thus cheat each other with Religious Frolicks.

div.trailer: The End of the Fourth Act.

div.head: The Fifth Act.
The Scene Bethlem.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: INdeed this is a fine place— the faireſt Hoſpital I ever ſaw.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Better than that of the Incurable of Venice; 'tis much for the Honor of the City, Madam: But did you never ſee it before, Madam?

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: No— nor had not now, had it not been to ſee my Friend Mr. Turbulent— The Sight of Bethlem, the Tombs, and the Lions are no Recreation for Ladies of Quality.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: 'Tis ſtrange Mr. Turbulent ſhould ſo ſoon become mad.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Indeed I had ſome Jealouſie of it the laſt time I ſaw him: For he told me I look'd Oldiſh. I thought indeed he was a little crack'd, to tell me I look'd Old— out upon him—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Why Madam, is that ſuch a Fault, Age is Honourable, and every body deſirous to live till they are Old: why then ſhould Old Age be ſo deſpicable?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Age is Honourable! marry come up— I ſay Age is not honourable— nor you for ſaying ſo— It is an old muſty Adage; and I ſay Age is good for nothing, but to ſpoil good Faces, brisk Wits, and active Bodies; to bring Wrinkles, gray Hairs, moiſt Eyes, ſlavering Lips, Aches in the Joynts, and Gouts in the Limbs— Age I ſay, is a moſt wicked and an abominable thing— and to tax me with it?—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Nay Madam, that indeed was a Crime.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Had he call'd me Whore, or Bawd, or Cheat or ſo, it had not vex'd me half ſo much — but poor man, he was out of his Sences—

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Monſieur Sneak, you be velcom to de Betlem; here is Monſieur Turbulent, and Monſieur Sucktum come here to be cured of de Melancholick, and you be come alſo in de very good time— you do very much vant de Ellebore.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I am well enough Doctor, I am not melancholly.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: You be de very melancholly man in de World — It is de melancholly dat trobles your Brain, dat makes you run here, run dere all day long, all de veek, all de year, after de project, and get noting, not one ſtraw, you'll be de true mel ancholly Pick-ſtraw.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam, this Doctor is like moſt of the World, they will not believe, till they ſee me in my Coach and ſix Horſes— Well Doctor, I ſhall convince you ſhortly— I will build an Hoſpital ſhall far exceed this—

sp.speaker: Dr. Que.
sp.p: Ay, dat is in de Brain— dere is one of de Wind-mills dat goes vur, vur, vur— dat is ven de project comes to perfection. I tell you Monſieur Sneak, vat you ſhall do vith your Money, you ſhall build tree ſuch Hoſpitals, one on each ſide of dis Square, and den dere will be four, one for each ſort of de Melancholly: dis vil hardly hold half de melancholly Pick-ſtraws in dis Town.

sp.speaker: Sne
sp.p: You are a jeering Doctor—

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Is there not one Mr. Turbulent here?

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Yes, he is above in the upper Gallery—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Now you are here, Madam, by all means ſee the mad folks— the Keeper will let you ſee them—

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Yes, you may ſee them if you pleaſe?—

div.stage: The Scene is drawn open, and diſcovers ſeveral ſorts of mad People.

sp.speaker: Lad. Med.
sp.p: Do you let them walk about looſe—

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Such as are harmleſs, and that are not raving, are permitted to walk here in this Gallery.

div.stage: Enter on the Stage a young Maid antickly dreſs'd, ſtaring and ſinging.

sp.speaker: Mad maid.

l.hi: Tell me prethee faithleſs ſwain,
Tell me prethee faithleſs ſwain,
Why you did ſuch paſſion feign,
On purpoſe to deceive me?
I no ſooner lov'd again.
But you began to leave me

sp.p: — Hey hoe— Are you Strephon? — No, no, you are not he; he had Garlands on his head— (Singing) Oh my Love's dead, and laid in his watry Grave. Pray tell me, did you ſee Strephon? — (Singing)

l.hi: You from my Embraces fly?

sp.p: Oh— there he is, there he is, ſtay, ſtay, ſtay, Strephon, ſtay.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Alas poor Maid.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: She is one that fell mad with Love.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de melancholly Fa la's, and Monſieur Finical Cringe vould do very well to keep her company, he is de madder of de two—

div.stage: Walk over the Stake, one in a Gown and Cap, reading in a Book, and not looking off.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: This is a Scholar that has crack'd his Brain in reading Ariſtotle— He is always poreing on a Book, but won't ſpeak in a week together.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dat is one of de melancholly Dumbſads; he no talk, he noting but tink, think, of de Philoſophy, and de ſtrange tings, till he has turned de Brain: He is de Brother to Monſieur Sucktum—

div.stage: Enter mad man paſſing o're the Stage.

l.hi: I'll pull down Honor from the pale-fac'd Moon,
And break the Wheels of the all-circling Sun.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: This is a mad Poet—he ran mad with making of Verſes— He ſpeaks them Ex tempore half a day together, and makes Love to all that comes near him in Rhime.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de melancholly Pick-ſtraws, dere be a great many in de ſame degree of Madneſs, dat goes about de Streets, and trobles de people vith dere Rhimes, and dere Nonſence —

div.stage: Enter mad man with many Papers in his Hand.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: So, the Marigold from Smirna— Cargo, Raiſons, Currance, Wine, Almonds, Silks, value 10000 l. The James and John from Genua, Cargo 5000 l. — The William and Mary, from Liſbon, laden with Sugars and Wine — Cargo 30000 l. —

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: This is a crack'd Merchant, doubly crack'd, firſt in his Eſtate, by the Loſs of a Ship or two taken by the Dutch, and afterwards in his Brain— but he is continually reckoning up his ſeveral Cargoes, that he fancies his Ships bring him from all parts, and ſumming up the Effects, and his Gains, he imagines himſelf the richeſt Merchant in the City of London.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: Alas! poor poor man—

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: 'Fait he be no poor man, he be de rich man in de Imagination: He is one of de melancholly Pick-ſtraws, and in de very ſame Degree of dis Shentilman, he tinks himſelf rich in de Project.

div.stage: Enter mad man holding his Head on one ſide, and learing off with his Hands.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Stand aijde, good Folks, ſtand aſide, leaſt I hurt you; pray give way— I'll gore you elſe.

div.stage: Exit, making motions with his Head, and holding it on one ſide, as if to get his Horns through the Door.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This is a Citizen that became Horn-mad through Jealouſie: He fancies that his Horns are ſo bigg, that he cannot carry them in the Gallery, and that they weigh down his Head, that he is fain to carry it on one ſide.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de Hypocondraic melanchollicks.

div.stage: Enter two habited like Scholars, with Caps and Gowns— diſputing—

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I think all Cuckolds are as mad as he, that would make their Inviſible Horns known to to all the World—but who are theſe Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Madam, they are two mad Critics, that when they get together, are continually diſputing about the Poets, Ancient and Modern: one calls himſelf Ariſtotle, and the other thinks himſelf Julius Scaliger.

sp.speaker: 1 Mad man.
sp.p: I ſay Mr. Ariſtotle, that the Poets of our Age, have nothing of Wit in them, and all their Peieces are falſe Draughts— O the wiſe Sophocles, the wiſe Euripides, the Oracles of their Age—

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: I ſay the Baye's, and the Ninnies of this Age are far beyond them, and they know more than they did, and write better Sence—

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: I ſay Ariſtotle thou lyeſt— The Ancient Ariſtophanes, and the witty Menander, were the only Perſons that underſtood Comedy among the Greeks— Terrence had ſome Wit; but Shakeſpear, and Ben. Johnſon were mere Oafs.

div.stage: Enter mad Woman, pulling Sneak by the Sleeve on one ſide.

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Are you married? —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What means ſhe by that? — I believe ſhe is in love with me—

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: I ſay Mr. Scaliger, you are a proud, malepert and impudent Critick, to find fault with the very Inſpired Prieſts of the Muſes; and I tell you, your Euripides, Sophocles, Ariſtophanes and Menander, and all the reſt of them were mere Ideots to the Poets of our Age.

div.stage: Enter mad Woman, pulling Sneak aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad. Wo.
sp.p: You are not matried, are you? —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Why do you ask? — No—

sp.speaker: Mad. Wo.
sp.p: Don't let the Keeper ſee me— I an't mad— I have 10000 l. to my Portion, and 500 l. a year, which a rich Uncle keeps from me in Berkſhire, and keeps me here, and makes People believe I am mad, only to keep my Eſta • e— I am no more mad than you are—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Sir, pray have a care of that Woman, ſhe is mad, and ſometimes very miſchievous— How came you looſe? — Go in —

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: You—See he won't let me tell you— but heark you— I'll marry you, if you can get me out.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: This was a happy coming hither. 'Tis ſo, the Keeper is afraid I ſhould diſcover it, ſhe ſpeaks very rationally— This was a very lucky chance— a happy Diſcovery—

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: I ſay you are a dull, inſipid, and ignorant Critick; and I ſay again, the Kings of your Poets, are no better than Punchenello's; they are ridiculous, and want Majeſty.

sp.speaker: Mad. Wo.
sp.p: You'll marry me then, and get me out of this place?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Pray Sir have a care of her, I give you warning.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Who is ſhe? —

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: A Stocking-mender's Daughter, that has run mad through Pride, and fancies ſhe has 10000 l. to her Portion, and 500 l. a year, in Berkshire—

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Do not diſturb dem, dey are de fitteſt to talk togeder dat I know: She hate de long Vorm in her Brain, and he hate de great Maggot in his: She fancies, ſhe hate de 10000 l. and he imagines, he hate de 100000 l. ven he has noting. Which is de madder den?

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Be ſure you keep my Council—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: And I will, and marry thee too, and get thy Eſtate — hah this is a lucky hit — I'll deal well enough with her Uncle, by the help of my Lady Medler—

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: Thou art a very venemous, wicked and reproachful Critick.

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: Thou art a ſcurrilous, ſurly, chymical Critick.

sp.speaker: 1 Mad.
sp.p: Thou art—

sp.speaker: 2 Mad.
sp.p: And thou art—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Hold, I'll end your Quarrel — I am ſo troubled with theſe mad Criticks, when they meet together: They always diſpute till they fall together by the Ears.

div.stage: Parts them, and turns them out ſeverally.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dere be many of deſe Greek Wits about dis Town, dat deſerve a place in dis Hoſpital; dey do noting but find de fault, and pick de hole in de Coat of de Poet, and de Wits: dey ſee de motes in de Sun, and de ſpots in de Moon, and de Stars: dey find de fault in de Lines, in de Verſe, in de Vords, in de Plays, vitout de Sence, or de Vit, or de Reaſon— Begar dey be all mad, and fit for de Betlem—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Madam I am very happy to day— I have made a moſt rare Diſcovery — I'll tell you anon, you muſt aſſiſt me in it— you ſhall have a Share Madam— I would not for a thouſand pound but I had come here to day—

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I am glad of the good Fortune—

div.stage: Enter out of his Cell a mad Man Chain'd, ſhaking his Chains, and roaring—

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: Pull down the Stars— hah, blow Boreas blow, make the Seas meet, daſh Rocks together, and put out the Sight of the Sun.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I'm afraid of him—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: You need not, he is faſt chain'd.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p:
Cerberus, doſt thou howl Cerberus? I'll cut off thy three Necks, and boyl 'em for that Lady's Supper— Avaunt, thou ſhe
Fury: I'll leap thee elſe like an Incubus — Tear 'em, tear 'em tear 'em—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Go, get you in— This is a frantick, outragious mad man.

div.stage: Exit mad man into his Cell.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis is one of de coloric Melanchollicks, dat is full of de rage, and de raving Fits, and is not as de Lunaticks, vith de lucid Intervals: Dis ſort, and de hot Brain, like de vild Fire— Here be all de ſorts of de mad men, and de melanchollicks in de Varld, and here dey take de Phyſick, and have de Cure for deir Malady and Diſtemper in de Brain.

sp.speaker: Mad.
sp.p: And now I am come to the nine and fortieth point, the downfal of the Whore of Babylon. Mark me, the Judgments of the terrible Approach of the falling into nothing, of the polluted and ſinful World, ſhall be turned and converted to Confuſion and Diſtreſs; and then, you ſhall behold the Crowns of the Earth, be tumbled on Heaps, and the Seas, and the Moon, ſhall vaniſh into Vapor— but then—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: This is a Fifth Monarchy Preacher, who employs himſelf this way all day long.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: He ſpeaks as ſoberly as moſt of dem, and as muſh Sence.

div.stage: Enter mad Woman again, pulling Sneak aſide.

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Let me tell you another Secret— You will marry me? —

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Yes—yes—and get you out; but take no notice then,

sp.speaker: Mad Wo.
sp.p: Heark you in your Ear.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Pray have a care Sir, of that Woman—

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh, oh, oh.

div.stage: Cries out ſhe bites him by the Ear.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: O Lord, Mr. Sneak, what ail you? —

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: I told you what would come of it—

div.stage: Keeper runs and takes her off, and turns out the mad Woman, who Exit laughing.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I think Mr. Sneak, you were madder than ſhe, to truſt your Ear in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Is this Mr. Grin Sneak the Projector?—

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Yes, this is Mr. Grin. Sneak—poor Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Oh Sir, I have an Order here to provide for you— I am glad you are come.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What mean you Sir?

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Only to carry you to your Companions, till I provide a Chamber for you— I have your Name here, Mr. Timothy Turbulent, Mr. Abednego Suckthumb, and Mr. Grin Sneak.

div.p: Here, carry this mad Gentleman to Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: What do you mean? — I an't mad—

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Sure he is not mad—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Here is Dr. Quibus, that receives a Penſion from the Houſe, and aſſiſts in the Cure of the mad Folks: He knows ſure, better than you Madam, who is mad, and who is not — I have his Hand for it, and an Order to provide for him.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui,
sp.p: He is de very mad man in de Vorld, I aſſure you.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: The Doctor underſtands nothing, I tell you I am not mad, and I won't go with you.

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: There is none of all theſe mad men that are here, but will ſay as much as you do; they do not think themſelves mad no more than you do.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: He vere not mad if he did not tink himſelf ſo—

sp.speaker: Keep.
sp.p: Have him away, I ſay — away with him.

div.stage: Exeunt carrying out Sneak between them, Keeper, men and Sneak.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Alas! poor man— I'll go after him—

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: I'll vait on you Madam—

div.stage: Enter Fairlove, Friendly, Cringe, Lucia, Priſcilla.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Now do I think this the fitteſt place in the World to conclude a Wedding in: For ſince you have been ſo mad as to put on the Fetters of Marriage, this Hoſpital is fitteſt for your Entertainment. I have ſeen you ſo mad, as to be married; but I deſpair of ſeeing your Cure— I doubt your Frenzy is for Life.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: It has coſt me ſome pains and ſtudy, to get my Uncle Turbulent hither; and now I have made ſure of Mr. Fairlove, and my Portion, I care not how ſoon he is releas'd.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Let him be cur'd firſt of his Turbulency. I doubt, all the Phyſick in London will hardly change his Nature— He feeds upon Choler, and he chews Galls and Bitterneſs, as if they were Eringo's or Marchpane.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: I think this Hoſpital is the fitteſt place in the World for all thoſe ſort of People; and if I were rich enough, I would add to its Revenue: For it is a great deal of pity, that theſe kind of mad men ſhould walk about the Streets as they do.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why Mr. Cringe— What are you muſing? — You are melancholly.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Who I? Fa la la la— I was only meditating upon an Epithalamium, which I intend to ſpeak my ſelf to my Bride at night, hey—hey—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Trouble not thy Head with vain Songs; plainly, they will be diſagreeing to me, and Mr. Goyle told me, Poetry was an unſanctified Vocation, and that all Poets and Players were hang'd up by the Tongues in Hell—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Mr. Goyle is a Lyar hey— for ſlandering the Poets hey— Thoſe were only the little bawdy, rhimeing, lampooning Poets; not thoſe that make Heroicks hey— I tell you, you ſhall hear my Epithalamium hey—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Do'ſt thou ſay, my Priſcilla is married to that vile rhimeng Fellow Cringe? —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes forſooth—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: And has my Neece married Mr. Fairlove, and got her Portion out of the Chamberlan's Hands?

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: Yes indeed, 'tis ſure enough — look you here, they are together.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Well— 'tis well my poor Husband is already diſtracted, elſe I'm ſure, this very News would make him mad.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Mr. Cringe, Speak— ſpeak to her— go—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: We have committed Matrimony forſooth Mother— Look you, I have taken Mrs. Priſcilla for better and for worſe, hey—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: You have taken her without my Conſent, Mr. Cringe, and conſequently without any Portion —

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: 'Tis no matter for that hey: I know how to go to Law hey— I married your Daughter upon a lawful Conſideration hey, and I ſhall force you hey—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Force me, force me? you impudent Ballad-maker: will you force me — Oh what Times do we live in! Force me—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Aunt, I'm afraid they'll think you mad as well as my Uncle. It is not good to be loud in this place, leaſt they provide a Chamber for you.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: I have taken care of your Neece, and taken her off your hands— I aſſure you, ſhe ſhall not trouble you any longer. I am now become her Guardian.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: In good time— Well Miſtreſs, I ſhall ſee you ſhortly live like thoſe at the other end of the Town; you in one Houſe, and your Husband in another: You with your Gallant, and he with his Miſtreſs, as they call 'em— You could not be contented with a good, honeſt, civil Shop-keeper.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have done you no hurt I hope, to beſtow the honeſt Shopkeeper you had provided for me upon your own Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Come mother, you ſhan't be angry hey, you ſhall get us a Sack Poſſet hey, and we will dance and be merry hey — Come away— let us go ſee my mad Father, hey—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I doubt this News will make him ten times madder— Paul, ſhew me the way to your Maſter.

div.stage: Enter Mr. Sly, and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Where is Brother Turbulent? we are come to ſee him in Tribulation, and to aſſiſt him with a word of Comfort.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: I fear Brother Turbulent is fallen away from his Principles, being ſeduced by his Nephew Furniſh; and now he ſuffers for his Backſliding,

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Are you freed from the Oppreſſion of the Aegyptian Dragon Right-or-wrong. How got you forth of the paw of the Bear?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: We were delivered.

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: What Canting is this?

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: This is the Language of the Saints.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: None of the Languages of Babel.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: How came you reconciled?

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: We have forgiven each other, leaſt the wicked and Reprobate ſhould reproach us for our Failings; and leaſt we ſhould become a Scandal, and a Stumbling Block to the Godly.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Mr. Furniſh is a vile, and an abominable man. Oh 'tis a wicked and unregenerate Age.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sly.
sp.p: Where Vice reigns triumphant, and runs down like a Stream—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Let us be gone, they are falling again into their Old Fits— The Round-houſe has not cured 'em.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: I am going to ſee Tim.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: We will go with you— my Bowels yearn, I am full of Compaſſion.

sp.speaker: Fair. Pollux
sp.p: — haſt thou beſpoke a Dinner over the way at the Popes Head—

sp.speaker: Pel.
sp.p: All things are ready for you— and I have beſpoke the Fiddlers: They will be here inſtantly, to play you to Dinner—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And we'll have one mad frisk among the mad Folks.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I like that Fa la la la—

div.stage: The Scene draws, and diſcovers Mr. Turbulent, Suckthumb, and Sneak ſitting together.

sp.speaker: Mr. Tur.
sp.p: They are a company of Rogues, Varlets, Cheats, Trapanners, Villains, to make me mad, and to feed me with Bread and Porridge— Theſe are Babylonian days— Oh the Oppreſſion of Pharoah, and the Tyranny of Dyoniſius.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Bear thy Tribulation with Patience, and be in the Meekneſs— We ſhall be delivered.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I have a Friend at Court that will ſoon releaſe me; and I will inform of the Abuſe.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I deſpiſe the Court, I hate the Court, 'tis a vile Abomination, and ſtinks of Prophaneneſs. Oh name not the Court, I cannot endure the ſound of it in my Ears.

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakeſt well, hold faſt to thy Principles, and thou ſhalt be delivered from the paw of the Lion.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I begin to doubt theſe two are mad— But I am not yet convinc'd, but the Woman as bit me by the Ear was ſober— She did it, that they might not ſuſpect our Plot— 'twas ſo.

div.stage: Enter Dr. Quibus and Lady Medler.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Here be de tree mad fokes, de ſeveral ſorts of de melanchollicks; dey make de very good Harmony.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: I am ſorry to ſee you here Mr. Turbulent; but they ſay, there is no better place in the World to get Cure— You have ſtudied too hard I doubt Mr. Turbulent.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p:
Do you come to jeer and mock me too? Are you one of the Reprobates? Ay, ay, you glory and fawn on the Evil Times—
you are a a very unſanctified Hypocrite, that you are — Pray be gone and meddle not with us.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Alas! poor man, I now ſee he is diſtracted.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I ſee you are an old medling Fool—

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p:
Old Fool! Old Fool! Thou art a diſtracted Aſs, •
• ad, hair-brain'd, raving Coxcomb. Old Fool—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Yes, thou art wrinkled in Iniquity, and grown hoary with Evil. Foh, thou ſmelleſt of the other end of the Town, and ar • combined againſt me.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: He is raving, ſtark mad — 'Tis well he is here, I could not have believ'd it, had not my Eyes ſeen it, and my Ears heard his madneſs.

sp.speaker: Mr. Sneak,
sp.p: how is it with you?

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I was thinking of the Woman that bit me by the Ear — I tell you ſhe is a great Heireſs.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: Well Mr. Sneak, I always took you to be a little craz'd; but now I find you are mad; and that nothing but good Diet and Phyſick will cure you.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Madam, de talk is very naught for de mad Folks; me vil give dem de Pill of de Ellebore; and you ſall ſee in de tree, or de fore days, dey vil be very much amended—Let dem tink, let dem tink.

div.stage: Enter Fairlove, Friendly, Cringe, Pollux, Mrs. Turbulent, Priſcilla, Keeper, Mr, Sly, and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Kep.
sp.p: Here are thoſe you enquire for, I ſhall provide them Chambers apart: For madneſs, like other Diſeaſes, is infectious; and they will hurt one another—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Tim.—How is it Tim.—Do'ſt thou know me Tim? thy own dear wife Tim.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: I know you for a Harlot, a conſpiring Harlot, a wicked ſhe Devil, to bring me here to Bedlam— But I'll tear thy Eyes out—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Alas! he is raving: Good Doctor Quibus, will you do your Endeavor. Do you think he will ever be his own man again?

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Do not fear: me vill give him de excellent Pill in de Varld: For de Cholerick melancholly; but he no eat de Caudle, nor de Turky Eggs; he no cram, cram, cram.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You are a Rogue, Doctor, and would ſtarve me here—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: He knows what is beſt for you Tim— but here is your Daughter Priſ. and your Neece come, to ſee you: do you know 'em Tim— They have committed Matrimony, and provided for themſelves.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Matrimony! Why, who are they are married to? —

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Why Sir, you not being compos mentis, I have made bold to chuſe me another Guardian, Mr. Fairlove here— I am his now—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: 'Tis well I am in Bedlam — I find I am mad now— wicked, abominable Varlet—you ſhan't have a penny of Portion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have ſecur'd that already Sir, you know the Clauſe in the Will— You are not compos mentis.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: You are a cheating Harlotry— I'll make you rue it—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I have got only my own, which you would have cheated me of—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: And who are you married to?

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Thy Rationallity is departed— and thou canſt not underſtand.

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: I an't aſham'd to own my Priſcilla hey— I married her to ſpite Mrs. Lucy— Shee agrees better with my Temper, hey— We ſhall do well enough if ſhe will like Verſes, hey—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: O vile diſobedient Wretch, marry a Poet, a maker of profane Verſes, a Lover of Songs and tinkling Inſtruments, a wicked, abominable, wretched, vile, profane adultrous—

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Hold— ſtop his mouth— he will loſe his Breath elſe— This Poet, and maker of profane Verſes, Uncle, you thought good enough for me— why are you ſo angry? —

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Away—away— vile, abominable, conſpiring Cheats— Inſtruments of Satan— get you together, go, begon — the mad people are much better Company: You are full of Defilement, Sin, Pollution, and Abomination, away, begon.

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: I am glad that in the midſt of thy Madneſs, thou holdeſt faſt to the Truth. Brother Turbulent, be comforted, and gird up thy Loyns, I hope thou wilt recover this delirious Fit; and that we ſhall again meet with a breathing forth, for the ſtrengthening and edifyin one another.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Go, get you together, I ſay I am not mad; but you are all a company of Fools and Cheats: This Uſage will cure me, and let me ſee my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Let us depart, Brother Turbulent is diſturbed; I doubt the Fumes of the unſanctified Wine are not yet out of his Head— Let him have reſt.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Go, go, take your turn in Morefields, with your black Patches, and yellow Hood, the marks of the Beaſt—

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Do not ſcandalize my Chicken— I'll take the Law of you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: Oh abominable, profane and reproachful mad man— I'll leave thee and thy madneſs together.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: So — ſo — the Brethers and the Siſters are falling to pieces.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Tur.
sp.p: Well Tim. I hope to ſee thee reſtored again to thy right Sences— Dr. Quibus will take care of you.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Will you leave me here then?

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p:
Dis is de beſt place for you in de Varld Mr. Turbulent; here you may be turbulent, and rail at the Times, at de Government, at de Governors: Here you may ſpeak de Treaſon all de
day long, vitout de danger of de Priſon, or of de Puniſhment.

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: But Maſter, they will not feed you well I doubt.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Rogue, Sirrah, Jack, Varlet, Raskal, Devil, do you prate? —

sp.speaker: Pol.
sp.p: What a many of Chriſtian Names have I? Well Maſter, fare you well, I have provided my ſelf of another Maſter here, Mr. Fair-love; but you firſt left me, and got a new Habitation.

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Let me go to my own Houſe I ſay— you will ſtarve me here— you Doctor Devil.

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Nay, dou ſhall have de Porridge in de Voden Diſh; dou ſhall have de boil'd Mutton, and de Bred, and de Beer, and de Pill of de Ellebore now, tree times de Week—

sp.speaker: Crin.
sp.p: Father Turbulent, fare you well, hey — We will talk of your Daughter's Portion hereafter, hey— Fa la la la la—

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dis de great pity Monſieur Cringe is not in de Betlem too— He very muſh vants de Cure: he is muſh trobled in de head vit de fa la—

sp.speaker: Fri.
sp.p: Oh let him alone, Doctor, he has got a worſe Bedlam behalf: His new married Wife will ſoon cure his-fa la— you ſhall ſee

sp.speaker: Dr. Qui.
sp.p: Dey be bote mad.

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: And will help to cure one another—

sp.speaker: Suck.
sp.p: I will ſhut my Eyes againſt the Vanities of the Earth, and will ſtop my Ears, that I may not hear the abominable Noiſe of the muſical Inſtruments: For this is a time of Tribulation—

div.stage: Pulling his Hat over his Eyes, and ſtopping his Ears.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: I will continue here willingly— I ſhall get the Opportunity of meeting with the Heireſs that is in Love with me— I ſhall get her, and that will be worth my Stay— Let them ſee who is mad then—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Oh I hear the Fiddles, they are coming — we will have one Dance among the mad Folks.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: But firſt, ſhut up my Uncle, he will be ſtark mad indeed elſe—

sp.speaker: Tur.
sp.p: Oh the wicked, abominable, riotous Age, Oh the noyſom Fiddles, the Provocatives to Lightneſs and Skipping together, like the Goats, frisking with their Tails of Wantonneſs—Fire Sword Plague, Peſtilence, Riot, Luxury, Chambering, Hell, Confuſion, Blood, Tempeſt, Storm, Thunder, Lightning, Hail and Hail-ſtones, fall on your—

div.stage: The Scene ſhuts in Turbulent, Suckthumb and Sneak.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So—ſo— I thought the Noiſe of the Fiddles would make • im ſtark mad—

sp.speaker: Sly.
sp.p: Let us be gone from the Carnal Noiſe of theſe lewd Inſtruments.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Sly.
sp.p: We will return to our Vocation— Oh the abominable Wickedneſs of this riotous Age.

div.stage: Exeunt Mr. Sly, and Mrs. Sly.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: So, we are rid of our Anabaptiſts.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: They would ſpoil our Sport, hey— they are not fit Company for us, hey—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: Plainly, theſe are the Carnal Inſtruments of Vanity.

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Don't ſpeak againſt 'em, hey— We will have a Dance, hey— Come, come, come, and you ſhall dance too, hey—

sp.speaker: Priſ.
sp.p: I will yield to thy Frailty.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Where is my Couſin Furniſh? We want him to make one here.

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: 'Faith Madam, it has been a fatal Morning with Mr. Furniſh— He is under Tribulation.

sp.speaker: L. Med.
sp.p: Where is he? what ails he?

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Alas poor man! Intending to come hither, a Brace of Sergeants, or Devils, which you will, ſnap'd him upon an Execution, and has carried him to the Coach and Horſes in Woodſtreet; From thence Madam, I am come to be his Solicitor to you, that you may redeem him this time, or he is utterly loſt.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Let him go to the Devil if he will — he ows me too much already—

sp.speaker: Frien.
sp.p: 'Faith Madam, that's unkind, I will ſpeak one good word for the Gentleman, though I'm a Stranger to him; becauſe he is ſo neceſſary an Evil the Commonwealth cannot be without. If it were not for ſuch as he, Fools having the Favor of Fortune, would not know what to do with their Money. 'Tis they get Riches, and ſuch as he eaſe them of the Burthen. They do but diſpend their money for them, and ſet it into motion.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Nay Madam, help him this once, I'll joyn with you— he ſhall never ſuffer on my Wedding day.

sp.speaker: La. Med.
sp.p: Well, tell him, he ſhall have the money ſent him anon— I'll make the Rogue pay me for't—

sp.speaker: Hang.
sp.p: Thank you Madam— So, I think it was well he was arreſted— He always comes off with flying Colors—

sp.speaker: Cringe.
sp.p: Come, you ſpoil our Sport, hey— Leave your Whiſpers and your Buſineſs till another time, hey— Fa la la la— Come Fiddles, ſtrike up—

sp.speaker: Fair.
sp.p: Come now, let us go over to the Pope's Head; you ſhall all be my Gueſts to day; and there Mr. Cringe ſhall have his Belly full of Dancing.

sp.speaker: Frin.
sp.p: I never was at a Wedding in Bedlam before.

sp.speaker: Fair.

l.hi: Fanaticks heve may ſafely have their Frollicks.

sp.l: The World's Great Bethlem, moſt men Melanchollicks.
